TRUMP TAX RETURN TRAVAILS: Everyone knows House Democrats want to get their hands on Trump’s tax returns, which he’s refused to disclose, and they can. The expected next chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Rep. Richard Neal (D-Mass.), will legally be able to examine them in private once the administration turns over the documents. But that transfer isn’t expected to be easy, and Democrats will face risks when they actually have Trump’s tax returns in hand, our Brian Faler reports. The reason? It's a felony to improperly disclose tax information, punishable by up to five years in prison.

Neal expects resistance when he calls for the Trump tax returns and foresees a legal battle ahead. “I assume that there would be some sort of a court case, but we’d have to wait and see,” he told the Washington Post. Trump during his press conference repeated his past claim that he couldn’t provide his tax returns because they are under a “continuous” audit, but added that even if they were released, “people would not understand them,” reports our Caitlin Oprysko. Asked whether he’d try to block Democrats trying to get them released, Trump told reporters at a post-midterm press conference that he “would have an open mind to it” when the audit was finished. Democrats aren’t buying it. “People know a cheat when they see one,” tweeted Senate Finance ranking member Ron Wyden (D-Ore.).

To avoid leaks, Neal shouldn’t cart Trump’s returns to Capitol Hill and instead should analyze the paperwork at the IRS, said Janice Mays, a former chief counsel for Ways and Means Democrats during her long tenure with the panel.

IRS INSIDE DOPE: The IRS is looking to tax professionals to assist its “Get Ready” campaign for the first tax filing season under the TCJA. “Despite all the work done so far (i.e. paycheck checkup), the taxpayer will likely be surprised and may be angry at the results,” National Conference of CPA Practitioners President Stephen Mankowski said in a recap of the October meeting of the agency’s National Public Liaison group. “While most taxpayers will see a decrease in tax liability, the withholding tables might result in lower refunds. Also, the IRS will be issuing communications regarding ‘what if the taxpayer owes taxes’ to help reduce anxiety. The taxpayer will then have a baseline for 2019 to make necessary changes.”

Other tidbits in the report: New 1040 forms and schedules will be available by mid-December. … The new tax deduction for non-corporate businesses remains an IRS priority. “There are still some issues to finalize before tax season.” … “There is a problem with the current CAF [Centralized Authorization File] system due to a 30% increase in breaches of tax preparer offices.”… Newly minted IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig dropped by the meeting. “Tom Cullinan, a tax attorney from Atlanta and former colleague of Rettig, will be joining the Commissioner’s office; however, we don’t know his title or position just yet. Overall, Rettig believes that the IRS can be more proactive with Congress as to what is working and not working.”

INSULT TO INJURY: Trump called out two Ways and Means GOP members on Wednesday for refusing his “embrace” and going down to defeat. “Peter Roskam didn’t want the embrace, Erik Paulsen didn’t want the embrace,” Trump told reporters, after reeling off several Republicans in tough races who welcomed his help. “On the other hand you had some that decided to — let’s stay away, let’s stay away,” Trump said. “They did very poorly. I’m not sure that I should be happy or sad, but I feel just fine about it.”

Reality check: Neither Roskam nor Paulsen was in a Trump-friendly district. In fact, Trump was probably a drag on them. Hillary Clinton carried Roskam’s district by 7 points in 2016 and Trump’s approval rating there was 36 percent in a pre-election poll by The New York Times and Siena College. Clinton took Paulsen’s district by 9 points and Trump’s approval rating was at 33 percent. Bloomberg said the TCJA’s new cap on deducting state and local taxes was a factor in their losses.

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

BRITS UNVEIL MORE DIGITAL TAX DETAILS: The U.K.’s planned digital services tax doesn’t violate international treaties on double taxation, according to a newly released consultation document from the government there, reports our colleague abroad, Nicholas Vinocur. The consultation also said the 2 percent tax on large digital companies’ revenue won’t have negative economic consequences. Speaking to reporters in Washington, U.K. Trade Commissioner for North America Antony Phillipson said minimal consumer impact is expected from the tax, which he said isn’t aimed at particular countries or companies, as I report. British officials aren't worried their digital services tax proposal will trigger U.S. retribution, Phillipson said.

PONDERING FACEBOOK PROBE: Facebook’s European tax arrangements could be facing an investigation by EU competition chief Margrethe Vestager “as she deepens her multinational investigation into sweetheart tax deals, two people close to the case said Wednesday,” reports our Thibault Larger. The company late last year announced it would alter how it pays tax on its global operations, but such changes can be immaterial to state aid cases because they focus on unpaid sums over certain periods in the past.

STATE NEWS

AMAZON JUNGLE: New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy swiped back at state Senate Minority Leader Tom Kean Jr. for saying that a boost in the state’s corporate business tax probably ruined its chances of luring Amazon’s new headquarters. Our Katherine Landergan reports that Murphy said at a press conference: "Taxes have never come up [with Amazon] in terms of what we did in the budget. I appreciate Sen. Kean weighing in. I notice he's weighing in a lot over NJ Transit over the last 9 months, bless his heart, I'd like to know we are fixing the damn thing. They broke it we are fixing it."

BIG SKY EDUCATION: More than 60 percent of Montana voters cast their ballots in favor of higher property taxes to help offset costs at the state’s four- and two-year colleges. “By mid-afternoon Wednesday the six-mill levy pulled in over 62 percent of the vote with almost 93 percent of precincts reporting,” said Montana Public Radio. That’s up from 56 percent when the measure was last on the ballot, in 2008. It has passed eight times in 70 years.

IN CONGRESS

Story Continued Below

DAY AFTER — SURVEYING THE AFTERMATH: The electoral tides have changed — and now it’s time to see who’s still afloat. While the exact scale of the changes is TBD, we can see the shape of what’s to come:

— The House: With Democrats taking the House, there will be a whole new cast of characters in leadership. Party leaders began to signal their upcoming moves Wednesday, and we can start to prognosticate what’s going to happen next. The best guess right now is that we will see Speaker Nancy Pelosi in 2019, though many in the incoming Democratic class have said they’d like to see change atop the caucus.

Further down the totem pole, Rep. Diana DeGette of Colorado has said she’s running for majority whip, the number three job in the House. That’s currently Rep. Jim Clyburn’s spot, meaning that we could see a high-profile race in caucus leadership. Long-time health care watchers know that DeGette, of Colorado, was one of the architects of the mammoth 21st Century Cures Act.

We also got a sense of committee chairs’ priorities. Rep. Frank Pallone, the presumptive leader of the Energy and Commerce Committee, circulated a list of priorities to reporters Wednesday. Of note on Pallone’s list: lowering health care costs; protecting net neutrality; and providing meaningful privacy protections. The last item on the list is particularly important: Pallone was opposed to the 42 CFR Part 2 rule overhaul that consumed so much attention during negotiations over the massive opioid legislation, and many observers are discussing the possibility of bipartisan national privacy legislation. Our Health Care colleague Adam Cancryn has a more in-depth look at the New Jersey pol’s priorities here.

Energy and Commerce’s Health Subcommittee is another a spot to keep an eye on: Rep. Anna Eshoo has said she’s interested in chairing the panel. The Silicon Valley Democrat has long been known as a telehealth booster.

One last potential committee chair to keep an eye on: Mark Takano at Veterans’ Affairs. Takano did a Q&A with our own Arthur Allen and broke down his priorities for the panel. The Southern Californian Democrat praised his predecessor, Phil Roe, for his bipartisan approach to committee business and said he’d continue it, were he to chair the committee. Takano said he’d be keeping an eye on the Cerner implementation at the VA, as he’d been interviewing potential staffers with tech backgrounds. “It will take some strong, technical expertise to oversee this,” he said. He also seems to be skeptical about the parallel implementation at Defense, saying, “My initial impressions of the early rollout [at the military] weren’t great.”

At a lower level, some in-doubt races got resolved — or close to it — on Wednesday. Texas Republican Rep. Will Hurd, who has focused on IT and cybersecurity issues, holds a narrow edge — just over a thousand votes — in his closely contested race against Gina Ortiz Jones. Wednesday afternoon, the Democrat vowed not to concede until all votes – which include overseas military ballots and provisional votes — were counted.

In New Jersey, meanwhile, Democrat Andy Kim holds a narrow edge over Rep. Tom MacArthur, a key dealmaker in Republicans’ 2017 quest to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

— Senate: Republicans tightened their hold on the Senate, though the exact composition of the upper chamber of Congress isn’t yet determined.

Still, GOP legislators signaled some of their priorities for the upcoming session. Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley may jump chairs — from Judiciary to Finance — a move that could presage tough oversight or reform bills, our colleagues Rachel Roubein and Sarah Karlin-Smith write. Grassley has been a longtime advocate for two eHealth-related issues: the Open Payments database displaying money that flows to doctors from pharma and device companies; and unique device identifiers.

Democrats scored a key hold, as Sen. Jon Tester of Montana prevailed by a thin margin on Wednesday. Tester, the ranking member of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee, helped end Ronny Jackson’s ill-fated nomination to lead the VA.

— The president: Donald Trump began a shake-up of his administration Wednesday, shuffling Attorney General Jeff Sessions off stage left. (Sessions, as we’ve previously reported, had been interested in using prescription drug monitoring programs’ data to crack down on the opioid crisis.)

In a long press conference, the president also signaled at least some willingness to work with the new House majority, saying he could work with Democrats on drug prices and social media regulation.

eHealth tweet of the day: Sarah Kliff @sarahkliff “[following up on previous report of needing to schlep a CD-ROM of X-rays from one doctors’ office to another] Addendum: got a call from my doctors office - the files on the CD are in the wrong format! So now we are just going to redo the x-rays.

Not because I *need* new x-rays, but because there isn’t a way to transfer the data.”

MEDICAID EXPANSION A HIT: Besides the hullabaloo over Congressional control, voters delivered a decisive verdict on another aspect of health policy: Medicaid expansion. Whether in referendum, or for politicians pledging to expand, voters blessed Medicaid, our colleagues Rachana Pradhan and Alice Miranda Ollstein write.

“This election proves that politicians who fought to repeal the Affordable Care Act got it wrong,” said Jonathan Schleifer, executive director of The Fairness Project, which bankrolled the Medicaid ballot initiatives. “Expanding access to health care isn’t a blue-state value or a red-state value; it’s an American value.”

RESEARCH CORNER

RESEARCH ROUNDUP: Some notable research and reports to share:

— Machine learning and epidemiology: A team of public health officials, Google techies, and Harvard researchers have built a new machine-learning model to detect foodborne illnesses. The model, described in a Nature Digital Medicine article, uses Google search data to zero in on queries suggesting foodborne illnesses, and then see what restaurants those users have been visiting recently. (That’s using location data, if you’re someone who’s squicked out by tech companies tracking you everywhere.)

A pilot run of their model in Las Vegas and Chicago found that identified restaurants were more than twice as likely to be found unsafe following an inspection.

Aside from whatever privacy qualms one might have, there’s one practical worry to keep in mind: Google Flu Trends, which used queries to estimate the incidence of the flu nationwide. It worked, until it didn’t. For technical reasons, the authors think this model is more reliable – but we suppose nothing is ever foolproof.

— Social determinant of health documentation: With increasing focus on the social determinants of health, a team of researchers wanted to know how frequently related data were documented in the EHR. The researchers, writing in Annals of Family Medicine, examined documentation at one system’s community health centers, and found it was limited. They said there are compelling reasons for recording the data – but noted that clinics need passionate staff to steward the concept.

TELECOM GROUPS BULLISH ON TV WHITE SPACES: Representatives from more than 40 companies are urging the FCC to modify its purview of TV white spaces, which operate on low frequencies and can, they say, easily and cheaply cover large areas. They say white spaces technologies are especially helpful in delivering broadband in rural areas.

Connect Americans Now requested that the FCC issue a notice of proposed rulemaking — in addition to its existing White Spaces efforts — outlining higher power for devices that these groups could operate on without interfering with broadcasters; and higher placement of antennas, among other things. Read the the letter here.

Infrastructure talk ramps up as election dust settles

With help from Brianna Gurciullo and Tanya Snyder

THE DUST SETTLES: There are still some ballots to be counted in Florida and elsewhere, but most of the key questions have been answered from Tuesday’s election. As expected, Democrats took back the House, and Republicans maintained control of the Senate. If you thought the two chambers couldn’t get along in this Congress, wait until you see what’s in store next year. Expect a ramp up of partisan bickering and two very different approaches to policy. With that said:

Yes, it’s infrastructure week: No, that joke isn’t going away. Leaders are already talking about infrastructure. Potential House Speaker Nancy Pelosi mentioned it in her victory speech, and the next day Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said it was an area he had already spoken to Pelosi about. “The one issue that leader Pelosi and I discussed this morning, where there could be a possible bipartisan agreement, is something on infrastructure,” he told reporters Wednesday. And during a press conference, President Donald Trump said Democrats “will come to us with a plan for infrastructure … and we’ll negotiate.”

Easier said than done: They may be talking the talk, but the walk is a very different story, as our Tanya Snyder wrote last month: Basic math and the tortured history of past infrastructure efforts suggest a tough road ahead. Plus, Trump didn't get very far with his $1.5 trillion package earlier this year, even with his party controlling both chambers. But one point in favor of collaboration: as The New York Times’ Maggie Haberman reminded on Twitter, “The president always told people he preferred the Dem infrastructure plan to the Republican one.”

New sheriff in town: Rep. Peter DeFazio (D-Ore.), who will become House Transportation chairman, is also bullish on infrastructure. “Welcome to the day after the election,” he told reporters Wednesday. “This is the day we begin planning to deliver a major infrastructure package.” He’s met with the White House legislative affairs director and plans to meet with her again, and he’s optimistic he can work with Trump on a bipartisan infrastructure plan with “real investment” — not “pretend stuff” like the asset recycling that former adviser DJ Gribbin put into Trump’s proposal. Get the full download here.

Don’t forget: There’s a push from some Democrats, led by Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.), to create an infrastructure subcommittee on Ways and Means, which would be a forum for House Democrats to focus on the issue that has long dogged infrastructure attempts: revenue. DeFazio said he “strongly supports” the concept.

LOOSE ENDS: Let’s get up to date on key transportation races that were still too close to call last time we were in your inbox. Commerce ranking member Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) is headed to a recount in Florida, although the initial tally suggests that he was beaten by Republican Gov. Rick Scott. Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.), a candidate for Transportation ranking member who had been trailing in the polls, has a lead against his Democratic challenger, but neither had conceded as of Wednesday night.

Other survivors: Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.), who stepped down from the committee in August after being indicted for campaign finance violations, won reelection, though his future is far from certain. Another committee member, Rep. Don Young (R-Alaska), the longest-serving member of Congress, also hung on despite early reports that his seat was in jeopardy. The Senate Commerce Committee’s Jon Tester (D-Mont.) also pulled out a late, turnaround victory.

Reax corner: American Association of Airport Executives President Todd Hauptli on the election results: “Concrete knows no political affiliation. It’s time to build.”

SAM GRAVES MAKES IT OFFICIAL: He’s running for Transportation ranking member. In a letter to the Republican conference Wednesday, the Missourian called himself “uniquely qualified,” and he launched a website laying out his vision for the committee. As he told POLITICO in an interview last month, Graves says his top priorities are crafting an infrastructure bill and finding a long-term funding solution for the Highway Trust Fund. As mentioned above, it remains to be seen whether he’ll have any competition. He’s been jockeying with Denham for the job for two years, but the Californian still has to emerge from his district before setting sights on the committee.

SUBCOMMITTEE SHAKEUP: Between retirements, promotions and election losses, there are plenty of changes cued up for the top spots on Transportation subcommittees. Most Democratic ranking members will move over to chairmanships, but as Tanya and Stephanie Beasley note, several subpanels will have new leaders including Highways and Transit, which will likely be taken by D.C.'s Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton, and Railroads, which has several contenders. There’s more uncertainty on the Republican side, with Denham and Graves facing uncertain futures.

GAS TAX TEA LEAVES: California’s rejection of a ballot measure aimed at repealing a 2017 gas tax increase was another defeat last night for Republicans, who had supported the referendum in hopes of boosting turnout. Some groups espect it will send a signal to Washington: “California voters showed the public continues to support a user funded approach to infrastructure investment. That’s a message the Trump administration and new Congress should heed as they consider a bipartisan infrastructure package and permanent revenue solution for Highway Trust Fund programs next year,” said William Toohey, acting president of the American Roads and Transportation Builders Association.

Aviation

LION AIR: FAA published an emergency directive Wednesday for those that operate Boeing 737 Max planes, about a week after the Lion Air crash near Jakarta that left 189 dead. The order is related to “possible erroneous angle of attack (AOA) inputs” on those planes, according to an agency statement. “These erroneous inputs can potentially make the horizontal stabilizers repeatedly pitch the nose of the airplane downward, making the aircraft difficult to control,” FAA said. Earlier this week, Boeing sent out a bulletin about the problem, as Bloomberg reported.

More to come? FAA said its emergency order, which demands an update to flight manuals, affects 45 planes in the U.S. operated by American Airlines, Southwest Airlines and United Airlines. It added that it “continues to work closely with Boeing, and as a part of the investigative team on the Indonesia Lion Air accident, may take further appropriate actions depending on the results of the investigation.”

Trucking

TRYING AGAIN: Tanya has a story for Pros on the American Trucking Associations’ latest argument that California’s meal and rest break rules should be preempted by federal law, via a petition to FMCSA. “At issue is an 80-year-old California labor law that grants workers a 30-minute meal break in a five-hour work period unless the workers are under a collective bargaining agreement that meets certain standards,” Tanya writes. “California's transportation industry regulations also provide for 10 minutes of rest time for every four hours worked.” The agency has rejected ATA’s logic twice before during different administrations, but this is the first time it will consider the arguments under the Trump administration. In a public comment period that ended last week, groups including the Teamsters and trial lawyers wrote in opposition to ATA’s effort.

SOMETHING FUN: If you need half an hour to zone out after the madness of this week, but don’t want to stray far away from transportation policy, check out the latest "Simpsons" episode. Homer gets fired from his job at the nuclear power plant, so he gets hired as a test driver for a new autonomous vehicle startup in town. Spoiler: Things don’t go well.

MIDTERM RAISE?: After securing a House majority, Democrats and labor unions are establishing priorities for the next Congress. Topping the list: an increase in the hourly minimum wage to $15, up from the current $7.25.

“The minimum wage bill will be one of the first we consider,” chairman-in-waiting Bobby Scott (D-Va.) told POLITICO’s Ian Kullgren. The legislation won’t be Scott’s own Raise the Wage Act, which would hike the wage minimum to $15 by 2024, but he says it will be “something very similar.” More for Pros here.

The AFL-CIO said during a press call Wednesday that the Democratic House should “take a hard look” at raising wages “in tandem with how the economy is producing.” AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka said the federation will also press for reining in drug costs, safety on the job, and retirement security.

“Even though Mitch McConnell has signaled he wants to pay for the tax cuts to the rich that they sent out by cutting Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, those will be at the very top of our list as well,” he added.

Your 2018 Midterms HQ: The countdown is on. Policy professionals know the 2018 midterms represent more than keeping track of winners and losers. The outcome of high-stake contests could dramatically alter the course of policymaking across the country. Go beyond election night with POLITICO Pro’s 2018 Midterms HQ. Read more.

BALLOT BOX

SCARE TACTICS WORK: “Pre-election fears by some Republicans that Trump’s inflammatory immigration message would sink GOP candidates in tight races proved overblown,” POLITICO’s Ted Hesson reports. “And while more authoritative analysis awaits further election returns and more detailed polling analysis, the message appears in some races to have worked.”

POLITICO tracked 21 close races in the House, nine in the Senate and four gubernatorial races across the country, based on information provided by advocates on both sides of the immigration issue. Of these, Democrats won 15 contests and Republicans won 12 contests. But Republicans led in six out of seven races that hadn’t been called by Wednesday afternoon.

As these numbers indicate, scare tactics on immigration worked more than they didn’t work. But, that doesn’t mean they always worked. Several Republican candidates closely aligned with President Donald Trump’s immigration agenda were defeated, including Kansas gubernatorial nominee Kris Kobach and Rep. Dave Brat of Virginia, Hesson reports. More from Hesson here.



Expect to hear more such heated rhetoric. White House aides say Trump’s midterm pitch on immigration is a preview of how he intends to play the issue with a Democratic House, POLITICO’s Megan Cassella, Nancy Cook and Gabby Orr report.

Officials say coming executive actions will allow “Trump to claim progress on fixing the broken immigration system, and to tell supporters heading into 2020 he did so without Democrats’ help.” Trump has already promised to restrict asylum claims for migrants who are caught crossing into the U.S. illegally and end birthright citizenship. POLITICO’s Ted Hesson reported late Thursday that the president “will take executive action, possibly as early as Friday, to limit the ability of migrants to seek asylum at the southwest border, an administration official confirmed Wednesday.” More from Hesson here and from the Wall Street Journal here.

But there may be a sliver of room for cooperation between Trump and likely Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi: The unsolved problem of what to do with the roughly 700,000 DACA recipients. It’s unlikely, though, that Trump will sign any bill that doesn’t include border wall funding or stricter enforcement measures. More here.

ACOSTA AG?: Trump is considering naming a permanent replacement for ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions, such as Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta, who has already been confirmed by the Senate. More from POLITICO's Eliana Johnson and Annie Karni here.

DEMS ARE HIRING: Bloomberg BNA’s Tyrone Richardson noted on Twitter yesterday that House Democrats were looking already to hire additional investigative counsel. A Daybook ad posted yesterday said Democratic staff on a House committee seek a lawyer to “conduct congressional investigations and advise on policy matters related to oversight of the executive branch.” Read the listing here.

Management-side attorneys Michael Lotito and James Paretti, Jr. of Littler Mendelson warn that potential hearings and subpoenas from the new House majority could further slow the already sluggish rulemaking process at agencies such as DOL, the NLRB, and OSHA. Increased oversight, they say, could “consume staff time and resources, delaying action on pending regulatory initiatives.” More of their analysis here.

NOT NICE AT VICE?: Vice Media will slim down, cutting loose as much as 15 percent of its staff, the Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. The company imposed a hiring freeze about six weeks ago and hopes to shrink its workforce through attrition. More from the Journal here.

BUSINESSES CAN PITCH THE PILLS: “The Trump administration on Wednesday released a set of rules that dramatically expand the ability of employers to claim a moral or religious exemption to Obamacare's birth control mandate,” POLITICO’s Alice Miranda Ollstein reports. “The change could roll back access to birth control for people who get their health insurance through work and is virtually certain to become ensnared in legal challenges. A similar effort was blocked last year after California and Pennsylvania secured injunctions that blocked the new policy from taking effect.” More for Pros here.

UNIONS

UNION INFLUENCE BY THE NUMBERS: 743 union members were elected in Tuesday’s elections, the AFL-CIO said during a press call Wednesday (some ballots are still being counted). Some 69.2 percent of the 52 Democratic House newcomers ran on a platform that supports unions, according to data compiled by the Progressive Change Institute. Another 61.5 percent campaigned on raising wages. “The overwhelming majority of incoming House freshman campaigned on economic populist issues, issues that impact working people,” said Adam Green, co-founder of the institute and the Progressive Change Campaign Committee. Take a look at the data here.

NLRB UNION TO DISTRIBUTE LEAFLETS AT ABA CONFERENCE: The union representing workers at NLRB headquarters plans to hand out leaflets at the American Bar Association conference in San Francisco today protesting General Counsel Peter Robb and Chairman John Ring’s decision to alter a collective bargaining agreement for workers at the D.C. headquarters. NLRB’s decision to renegotiate the agreement implemented one of President Donald Trump’s executive orders on the federal workforce, but these were struck down in federal court. Several agencies, including the NLRB, have nonetheless sought to renegotiate agreements while the Justice Department appeals the decision.

“Robb and Ring continue to threaten Agency employees with unnecessary and unfair cuts to employment conditions,” the leaflet reads.

“The Agency’s current leadership cast aside years of a peaceful, collaborative relationship with its employees by terminating our contract and, by all accounts, preparing dramatic cuts to employees’ benefits, job protections, and compensation—even though there has been no funding change to the Agency and it ended the last fiscal year with a significant budget surplus,” Karen Cook, the NLRB Professional Association president, said in a statement to Morning Shift.

Coffee Break

— “Forget taxes, immigration and health care. The first step for House Democrats is to change the way Congress works.” from The Washington Post

— “Hospitals Torch Safe Staffing Limits in Massachusetts,” from Labor Notes

— “What Democratic Control of the House Could Mean for Your Wallet,” from The New York Times

— “Trump indicates he'd consider raising some taxes to win middle-class relief,” from POLITICO

THAT’S ALL FOR MORNING SHIFT.

Renewed hope for HEA?

With help from Caitlin Emma

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

HEA HEAT CHECK: The Democrat expected to take over as chairman of the House education committee says updating the Higher Education Act is a top priority come January. Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), now the ranking member on the House Education and the Workforce Committee, told Morning Education’s Kimberly Hefling he's hopeful Congress can pass a bipartisan bill to update the federal law governing higher education that President Donald Trump would sign. Observers, however, say he’s dreaming.

— Scott said he’d like to see the committee start with House Democrats’ "Aim Higher" bill, H.R. 6543 (115), that he and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi announced over the summer, with the goal of reaching out to House Republicans to get their input. “If it’s got no Republican support, you can’t believe it would have much of a chance in the Republican Senate,” Scott said.

— He also criticized Republicans' handling of their partisan PROSPER Act, arguing that Democrats didn't get enough notice to review it and contribute to the process. “I would hope we would be able to start with the Aim Higher Act, go through the regular process of having hearings, giving people the opportunity to have input, and fashion a higher education bill that actually improves access to higher education, make sure that educational opportunities are available for those who want to get specific job skills but basically improve access to and affordability of higher education," Scott said. Kim has the full story.

— Not so fast… “The fundamentals of passing an HEA reauthorization bill haven’t changed,” said Craig Lindwarm, assistant vice president of congressional and governmental affairs at the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities.

— It still comes down to the Senate, where negotiations between Sens. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn) and Patty Murray (D-Wash.) fell apart this year. Murray might have a little more leverage with Democrats in control of the House, Lindwarm said, but Alexander is still HELP chairman, Republicans still control the Senate and Trump still would have to sign the bill.

— Silver lining? Alexander “wants to get this done more than ever,” said Terry Hartle, senior vice president of the American Council on Education, the main higher education lobbying group. Alexander, he noted, is term limited in his role as chairman and up for reelection in 2020. “There will be people in both houses who are very anxious to move the legislation forward, but the overall political climate is so toxic that it’s hard to imagine them making much progress,” Hartle said.

— “While there is much day-after-elections talk of bipartisanship, it is hard to see the two sides working together in the lead-up to the 2020 cycle,” said Barmak Nassirian, director of federal relations and policy analysis at the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The normal collegial instincts of incumbents to pass legislation before facing the voters will quickly give way to demonstrations of ideological purity as each party seeks to energize its base.

— “Something like the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, which beyond partisan philosophical differences also involves significant federal costs, would be even less likely to happen, given the inevitable blame game and finger-pointing around fiscal responsibility and the deficit,” he said.

Your 2018 Midterms HQ: The countdown is on. Policy professionals know the 2018 midterms represent more than keeping track of winners and losers. The outcome of high-stake contests could dramatically alter the course of policymaking across the country. Go beyond election night with POLITICO Pro’s 2018 Midterms HQ. Read more.

MIDTERMS WATCH

TEACHER STRIKES AND THE MIDTERMS: The #RedforEd movement that rocked some state capitals earlier this year — which teachers unions sought to harness as thousands of educators demanded better school funding and salaries — didn’t break through in Republican strongholds that saw the most unrest. But teachers still notched some big victories, Caitlin Emma reports.

— Democrats seized some GOP-held governorships on Election Day but failed to take others — including in Oklahoma and Arizona, where the walkouts consumed state capitals and made national headlines. Some state legislative chambers flipped, but Republicans maintained control in Arizona and West Virginia, another state with massive walkouts. It was also a mixed bag for state ballot initiatives and teachers and education activists running for office. Read more.

— “There is no doubt that the results of tonight's major race was disappointing,” Oklahoma teacher Alberto Morejon wrote on Facebook Tuesday night. Morejon helped orchestrate the teacher walkouts there, galvanizing tens of thousands of educators through a Facebook group that he still maintains.

— The disappointment came in the Oklahoma governor’s race. Republican Kevin Stitt beat Democrat Drew Edmondson by double digits. Edmondson supported the tax hikes designed to fund teacher raises in the state as a response to the teacher unrest. But Stitt didn’t support the measure or new taxes. “I know its [sic] not the outcome we wanted tonight ... but hold your head up high, because there is so much to be proud about,” Morejon wrote to his thousands of followers.

— Teachers unions and public education advocates scored two major wins, however. Tony Evers, the Democrat in charge of Wisconsin's public school system, narrowly defeated Republican Gov. Scott Walker, who was seeking a third term. And in Kansas, Democrat Laura Kelly defeated Republican Kris Kobach. Kobach backed a state law that would require 75 percent of school funding to be spent on classroom instruction and once compared school buildings to “crystal palaces.”

SUPER CLOSE SUPERINTENDENT RACES: A trio of state education chief races — in Idaho, Arizona and California — came down to the wire, with two still seemingly too close to call.

— In California, Tony Thurmond, a Democratic state legislator and former social worker backed by teachers unions, refused to concede to fellow Democrat Marshall Tuck, who led by about 80,000 votes on Wednesday. “With millions of ballots left to be counted, we're digging in & waiting for every vote,” Thurmond tweeted. “The kids of CA are in it for the long haul & we are too. I’m so proud of the coalition we built & I thank the thousands of educators, students & public ed advocates who supported our campaign.”

— The race was closely watched, in part, because it generated more than $40 million in contributions. Tuck, the former president of a charter school organization who also was the CEO of an initiative that runs 18 district schools in Los Angeles, lost his bid for the nonpartisan seat in 2014. He was the heavy favorite among members of the education reform community, which favors charter schools.

— The race in Arizona was nearly tied late Wednesday. Frank Riggs, a Republican charter school executive and former California congressman, was leading Democrat Kathy Hoffman, a speech pathologist and political newcomer with ties to the #RedforEd movement, by just more than 6,000 votes — less than half a point. “There are still votes left to count, and I want every voice for public education to be heard,” Hoffman tweeted on Wednesday.

— Idaho's Republican schools chief Sherri Ybarra on Tuesday held off a challenge from Democrat Cindy Wilson, a high school government teacher, in a tight race for the state's top education job. Ybarra held a nearly 3-point lead over Wilson, who campaigned on improving early childhood education and criticized a $20 million school safety proposal by Ybarra that focused heavily on hiring school security personnel. Ybarra has said she is committed to awarding master teacher bonuses.

ON THE HILL

HOUSE GOP SHUFFLE COMING ON EDUCATION COMMITTEE: The House education committee is set to lose at least seven Republican members in January. Two GOP incumbents on the panel lost their reelection bids Tuesday. In Virginia, Rep. Dave Brat was unseated by Democratic challenger Abigail Spanberger. And Rep. Jason Lewis lost in Minnesota to Democrat Angie Craig.

— Meanwhile, Republican incumbent Rep. Karen Handel of Georgia was trailing her Democratic opponent, Lucy McBath, by fewer than 3,000 votes on Wednesday in a race that has not yet been called. Those three potential losses come after four GOP members of the education committee did not seek reelection. Michael Stratford has the full rundown.

EDUCATION DEPARTMENT

FEDERAL EMPLOYEES UNION ASKS CONGRESS TO INVESTIGATE DEVOS: The American Federation of Government Employees, which represents Education Department workers, is calling on Congress to investigate Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’ planned reorganization of the agency. That inquiry could happen, as Democrats are now expected to ramp up their oversight of DeVos after gaining control of the House.

— AFGE President David Cox said in a statement that DeVos is “pushing through a sweeping reorganization that will result in many employees being displaced or moved into other jobs without the proper training or experience.” He said, “Secretary DeVos is undeterred and single-minded in her quest to decimate the Department of Education by making the agency such a miserable and untenable place to work that even the most dedicated employees will quit. We need Congress to step in now before more harm can be done.”

— Morning Education recently reported new details about the department’s reorganization, including an overhaul of the office that deals with student data privacy and an elevation of the private school office so that it reports directly to DeVos. Education Department spokeswoman Liz Hill said at the time the reorganization effort is “focused on streamlining our internal processes in an effort to make the department more efficient, coordinated and responsive for students, educators, parents and taxpayers.”

THE WHITE HOUSE

TRUMP ON DACA: ‘WE’LL SEE HOW IT WORKS OUT AT THE SUPREME COURT’: Asked whether he’d work with Democrats on a deal to grant deportation relief and work permits to roughly 700,000 undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children, Trump said he’ll leave the issue to the Supreme Court.

— “We could have done some pretty good work on DACA but a judge ruled that DACA was okay,” Trump said during a contentious press conference Wednesday. “Had the judge not ruled that way I think we would have made a deal. Once the judge ruled that way, the Democrats didn't want to talk anymore. … We'll see how it works out at the Supreme Court.”

— The Justice Department this week petitioned the Supreme Court to intervene in several cases over the termination of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which Trump moved to end in September 2017. A San Francisco-based federal judge in January barred the Trump administration from ending the program and ordered it to resume processing DACA renewals. Two other federal judges followed with rulings against the termination. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals heard oral arguments in May but has not yet ruled on the matter.

ALSO: Shortly before firing Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Trump insisted he’s “very happy with most of my Cabinet. … We’re looking at different people for different positions. You know, it’s very common after the midterms. I didn’t want to do anything before the midterms, but I will tell you that for the most part, I’m extremely happy with my Cabinet.”

REPORT ROLL CALL

— DeVos on Wednesday released a guide to help parents understand the report cards that states and school districts are required to publish under the Every Student Succeeds Act, detailing school performance.

SYLLABUS

— The midterms showed the diploma divide is likely here to stay: The Atlantic.

— "Scott Walker is out. Can a new governor save higher ed in the Badger State?:" The Chronicle of Higher Education.

— A Kentucky school district outlines plans to improve after at least two recent incidents of educators dragging students with autism: Lexington Herald-Leader.

— Aide: Gov.-elect Bill Lee “misspoke” when characterizing Tennessee schools as bottom of the nation: Chalkbeat.

— Hundreds of Anchorage educators walked out of a school board meeting before contract negotiations between the school district and teachers union: Anchorage Daily News.

— Board discusses ways to save Rhode Island special education organization: WJAR.

Peterson predicts farm bill gets done this year

With help from Helena Bottemiller Evich and Catherine Boudreau

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

IN THE HOPPER: The farm bill is on track for a lame-duck finale, says the (likely) incoming House Agriculture chairman. After the farm bill gets done (and it seems like it’ll be a big “if” until it actually passes), Rep. Collin Peterson says House Democrats will eye stepped-up oversight of USDA next year, as we previewed in our Election night coverage.

— Didn’t get enough of the midterms? MA has all the late-breaking House and Senate farm-state results (and recounts!) that rolled in Wednesday.

— Republicans romped to victory in state agricultural commissioner races in Georgia, Iowa, North Dakota and Texas, but Florida’s contest is likely headed to extra innings.

— Health advocates are licking their wounds after Washington voters approved a state ballot initiative to stymie new soda taxes. Oregon voters took the opposite tack, foiling beverage makers, who dreamed of forming a West Coast wall against new taxes on sugary beverages.

PETERSON, THE FARM BILL AND 2019: Farmers and ranchers can look forward to a final farm bill before the end of the year, the current House Agriculture ranking member told reporters Wednesday, saying that farm bill negotiators are getting “relatively close” — whatever that means — to an agreement for a final measure that Congress can pass during the lame-duck session.

— Ag industry groups fear that starting the farm bill process anew in 2019, with Democrats controlling the House, would mean a flurry of amendments contrary to industry’s interests, like stricter subsidy limits and checkoff changes, writes Pro Ag’s Helena Bottemiller Evich.

The commodity title is still not settled, but a handful of options are on the table for negotiators to consider, Helena reports.

On the nutrition title, Trump made what amounted to a potential threat to veto a farm bill lacking stricter work requirements for Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program recipients.

“We could have a very fast [bill] without the work rules, but we want the work rules in,” Trump said during a post-election press conference that lasted almost 90 minutes.

Oversight areas: Democrats could scrutinize Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue’s plans to relocate the Economic Research Service and National Institute of Food and Agriculture, other USDA efforts and, potentially, checkoff controversy, Peterson said.

Flashback: Our look at Peterson as chairman amid a blue House wave.

HAPPY THURSDAY, NOV. 8! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host hopes the famous Central Park mandarin duck turns up soon. Have any news or tips? Send them to rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon, and follow the whole team @Morning_Ag.

As the exclusive media partner of the summit, POLITICO journalists will provide firsthand insight and intelligence on timely political and policy issues facing the military and military spouses. RSVP here.

THE FARM-STATE POLITICAL LANDSCAPE: Election results from agricultural regions kept coming in Wednesday, headlined by Democratic Sen. Jon Tester’s reelection in Montana. The organic farmer, who lost three fingers to a meat grinder at age 9, pulled off the narrow win over Republican state auditor Matt Rosendale. It’s Tester’s third-straight Senate election win with 49 percent of the vote in mostly red Montana.

— In California’s Central Valley farmlands, Republican incumbents had a good night. Rep. Jeff Denham, a top Democratic target, had a slim lead over Democrat Josh Harder as votes were still being counted Wednesday evening. Voters also sent GOP Reps. Devin Nunes and David Valadao (both dairy farmers) back to D.C. for two more years.

— Californians also approved Proposition 12, a ballot measure that requires more housing space for certain hens, pigs and calves. Out-of-state producers will also need to meet the new “cage-free” production standards to sell their goods in the Golden State. POLITICO’s Sarah Zimmerman has the Prop 12 details.

— A rare House GOP pickup: Republican Jim Hagedorn narrowly defeated Democrat Dan Feehan for the open Minnesota seat now held by Democrat Tim Walz (who was elected Minnesota governor on Tuesday). It’s one of the only House districts that Republicans flipped from blue to red this cycle.

— GOP candidates cleaned up in state ag commissioner elections: Incumbents like Sid Miller in Texas, Gary Black in Georgia, Mike Naig in Iowa, Doug Goehring in North Dakota and Hugh Weathers in South Carolina were all reelected.

THE FLORIDA RECOUNT FRENZY: At least five races in Florida appear destined for a recount, including the contest for state ag commissioner between Republican state Rep. Matt Caldwell — who has close ties to Florida’s outgoing top agriculture official, Adam Putnam — and Democratic challenger Nicole Fried.

— In the state’s U.S. Senate race, Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson was trailing Republican Gov. Rick Scott by fewer than 35,000 votes (0.4 percentage points).

Caldwell led Fried by just 0.16 percent of the vote at one point on Wednesday, per the Tampa Bay Times. A Florida state Senate race and two state House races also were headed for a recount, and the governor’s race, with an excruciatingly close vote tally, appeared like it too would be forced into a review, POLITICO Florida’s Alexandra Glorioso reported.

— Recounts likely won’t be ordered until this weekend, as ballots won’t be fully counted until Saturday at noon. Federal, state or multicounty races separated by 0.5 percent or less, will automatically undergo a machine recount, due Nov. 15. Those separated by 0.25 percent, or less, will automatically undergo a manual recount by Nov. 18.

Fried, an attorney and lobbyist for the state’s growing medical marijuana industry, said in a statement Wednesday that she is “going to ensure that every vote is counted.”

— What’s at stake in the ag race? Sway over local handling of issues like water quality and delivery of hurricane relief. Florida’s sugar industry, often blamed for the toxic blue-green algae blooms in Lake Okeechobee and along the Gulf Coast, contributed upwards of $1 million to Caldwell’s campaign, the Miami Herald reported in August — more than Fried had raised overall at the time.

Caldwell has said Big Sugar is used as a “scapegoat” for Florida’s pollution problem, with rapid urban development also part of the problem.

HEALTH ADVOCATES DECRY STATE SODA TAX LOSS: The beverage industry didn’t succeed Tuesday night in setting up a legal blockade against soda taxes on the West Coast, but Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and other companies did score a major win in Washington state with the passage of Initiative 1634.

The measure, up 55 percent to 45 percent with votes still being counted Wednesday evening, prohibits new soda taxes statewide, though Seattle’s existing tax on the sugary beverages won’t be rolled back. In Oregon, voters rejected the similar Measure 103 overwhelmingly (43 percent to 57 percent).

Money questions: The results, which run counter to what polls were showing, raise interesting questions about whether health groups put their money in the right places this cycle.

Billionaires Michael Bloomberg and Laura and John Arnold — major soda tax backers — together poured $3 million into Oregon, where there was already organized opposition to the tax measure (alongside other ballot questions). But no funding from either major source was spent in Washington. That left advocates there with no resources for TV ads or mailers while major beverage companies unloaded more than $20 million to promote the tax ban.

American Heart Association is bummed: AHA, the only major donor in Washington, said the fight for soda taxes is not over. “For sure this is a setback, but it’s imperative that we continue to address chronic diseases such as heart disease, stroke, tooth decay and Type 2 diabetes in both children and adults with innovative public health policies,” said Mary Ann Bauman, a Seattle doctor on AHA’s board.

ROW CROPS

— House leadership moves: Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) will run for GOP minority leader, as will Freedom Caucus co-founder Jim Jordan (R-Ohio). On the other side of the aisle, Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) will run for Democratic majority leader, the post he held when Democrats last held the House majority. Catch up with POLITICO’s Rachael Bade and John Bresnahan.

— Trump open to corporate tax changes? The president said he would be willing to make an “adjustment” to recent tax cuts for corporations and wealthy individuals in order to attract Democratic support for additional middle-class tax cuts. Pro Tax’s Toby Eckert has more.

— The pork-soybean-corn triumvirate: The National Pork Board, United Soybean Board and National Corn Growers Association agreed on a “sustainability research platform,” aiming to share and coordinate research on farm resilience and conservation. Here’s the announcement.

— No chairmanship news from Grassley: Sen. Chuck Grassley didn’t announce which Senate committee he wants to chair in 2019. The Iowa Republican said he’ll talk it over with his colleagues when the Senate reconvenes Nov. 13 before deciding whether to keep his post as Judiciary Chairman or take over the Finance Committee. Here’s more from Pro Tax’s Aaron Lorenzo.

— GMO bugs and bio-weapons? The Defense Department is funding research into genetically modified insects and viruses that can help plants survive droughts and provide other benefits. Some scientists are skeptical the program is really about saving crops — rather than biological warfare capabilities. NPR has the story.

— What is ‘deferred maintenance’ in inland waterways? Good question — a new GAO report found that the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers “does not know how much deferred maintenance exists” on locks and dams throughout the inland waterways system because it lacks an agreed-upon definition of the term. The report listed that as a main reason why funding infrastructure upgrades throughout some 12,000 miles of inland waterways has been so challenging. Sarah has more.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! See you again tomorrow. In the meantime, drop us a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.

What 2018 election security teaches us about 2020

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PRETTY GOOD, NOT GOOD ENOUGH — The midterms didn’t have any visible major election interference, and that at least partially reflects good legwork by the feds, according to experts, state officials and others who spoke to Eric and your MC host Wednesday— but there’s more work to be done, they said. Other possible explanations for the quiet midterms include Russia taking a break before the bigger election next cycle, DOJ indictments deterring attacks or successful meddling attempts that simply went unnoticed.

Among the recommendations for preparing for 2020? Better coordination between states and social media companies, and more funding to improve voting machines that suffered technical glitches, thus further revealing their security vulnerabilities. Pros can read the full story here.

HAPPY THURSDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! Didn’t see this one coming. Welcome back, Jesse. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com, and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

Topics include improving the financial stability of military families and using tech to tackle the high unemployment rate of military spouses.” RSVP here.

HOUSE DEMS BEGIN TO ASSEMBLE PLANS — It’s early, but some House committees due for Democratic takeover are signalling some of their cybersecurity-related plans. A spokesman for top Homeland Security Democrat Bennie Thompson, Adam Comis, told MC on Wednesday that panel Democrats would certainly focus on election security, “lack of cyber leadership from the White House” and the security of the supply chain.

“Committee on House Administration Democrats intend to advance sweeping legislation to overhaul our election security systems and standards to protect and secure our elections from interference, providing funding for states that move to an auditable, paper ballot system, and imposing greater vendor oversight,” Peter Whippy, a spokesman for panel Democrats, said. Current top Democrat Robert Brady is set to depart. Rep. Zoe Lofgren is the panel’s most senior Democrat, and she is expected to take the gavel next, a senior Democratic aide told MC.

Rep. Frank Pallone, top Democrat on the Energy and Commerce panel, listed “meaningful privacy and data security protections” as among committee priorities in a news release. And Eddie Bernice Johnson, top Democrat on the Science Committee, said the panel would emphasize science, technology, engineering and mathematics education, a key element of building up the cybersecurity workforce.

Republicans also began throwing their hats in the ring for vacancies on the minority side of panels. Ashley Phelps, communications director for current Administration Committee vice chair Rodney Davis, said the Illinois Republican is “qualified and well prepared to be Ranking Member of the committee if appointed by the next Minority Leader.” She added that Davis “has worked in a bipartisan way to lead the committee on important reforms such as shared employees, workplace harassment, and security improvements.” Rep. Randy Weber announced his attention to seek the top Republican post on the Science panel.

DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE

SESSIONS OUT, WHITAKER IN; NEXT? — Incoming acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, whom the White House announced Wednesday is replacing Jeff Sessions, has previously suggested starving the budget of special counsel Robert Mueller, a move that could hamper any future pursuit of 2016 election Russian hackers and trolls. Mueller has delivered indictments against the alleged Kremlin-backed hackers who infiltrated Democratic emails and the “troll farm” that spread propaganda and discord. With Sessions’ departure, deputy AG Rod Rosenstein will no longer oversee Mueller’s probe, instead handing control to Whitaker. Whitaker also has said prosecutors should have indicted Hillary Clinton over her use of a private email server.

Although much of DOJ’s enforcement efforts and court fights on cybersecurity are done at the staff level and can be expected to continue, Sessions had made cyber a part of his agenda. He created a cybersecurity task force this year, which released a report outlining cyber threats to the U.S. and the tactics DOJ would use to combat them. Sessions was part of the Trump administration’s public campaign to gain access to encrypted communications. He voiced concern about the security threat posed by China buying stakes in U.S. tech companies, and accused China of violating a 2015 deal prohibiting cyber theft from U.S. firms for commercial gain. But Democrats blasted him as inattentive to election security.

The two favorites of oddsmakers to replace Sessions on a permanent basis, Rudy Giuliani and Kris Kobach, would bring their own baggage to the issue. Giuliani led a cyber working group for Trump that apparently did nothing. The Trump administration’s Kobach-led voter security commission took fire over its handling of sensitive voter data.

THANKS, RUSSIA — After careful study, Russian observers found no irregularities with Tuesday’s elections. The monitors, deployed through the Parliamentary Assembly of the OSCE, uncovered no discrepancies at the nine polling stations they visited in Maryland and Washington, D.C., MP Alexey Korniyenko told Russian news agency TASS. “The polling station employees were very cordial and answered all our questions,” he said. “Some of them also talked in detail about the election process and voting equipment.”

INTERESTING PARTNERSHIP — Russia and Spain this week formed a cybersecurity working group designed to resolve conflicts over the spread of misinformation. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said he discussed with his Spanish counterpart how “some Russian mass media go beyond the limits of their professional activity and create inadmissible interference in other countries’ issues.” But he said it wasn’t due to the Russian government’s involvement, even though several of the most prominent Russian news outlets are state-owned.

HOT FIELD — U.S. government and private-sector employers had more than 300,000 cybersecurity-related job openings as of August, according to data from the workforce analytics website CyberSeek, and cybersecurity workers are in higher demand than workers in general. “Across all occupations, there are currently 5.8 employed workers for every job opening. Within the cybersecurity field, the ratio of existing cybersecurity workers to the number of cybersecurity job openings is 2-to-3,” the technical standards agency NIST said in a statement. “That means employers have fewer trained cybersecurity workers in the labor force to choose from and must look to other tactics—including retraining current workers or attracting and training new talent—to fill their needs for cybersecurity professionals.”

The statistics are based on data collected between September 2017 and August. CyberSeek, a partnership between NIST, the analytics firm Burning Glass and the trade group CompTIA, is part of the government’s effort to bring more concrete statistics to the often-nebulous problem of the cyber workforce gap. The site breaks down jobs into several categories, including “Operation and Maintain” and “Protect and Defend.” Unsurprisingly, Washington, D.C., is the top spot for cyber job openings, followed by New York City and Dallas.

ENSURING BETTER CYBER INSURANCE — Insurance companies can do more to protect private companies against cyberattacks, according to a report from the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace released Wednesday. Governments can only help the private sector so much due to corporate reluctance to accept federal interventions and regulations, the report states, and the private sector simply does not have the resources to protect itself against sophisticated hackers.

Current cyber insurance policies are limited, the report states, but insurance companies can take a larger role in understanding and managing cybersecurity risks. Insurance companies can create risk management practices while identifying and shaping trends in cybersecurity, the report states, effectively reducing the strain on government and corporate resources.

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries' move to become House Democratic Caucus chair is sure to shake up the race. | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik Congress Jeffries makes move for Democratic leadership position

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries is launching a bid to become House Democratic Caucus chair, a move some of his supporters hope would position him to one day become the first black speaker should he win.

Multiple critics of Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi have been trying to get the Democrat from Brooklyn to challenge her for the job. Jeffries, while only 48 and just elected to his fourth term, is well liked in the Democratic Caucus and is seen as a rising star.

Story Continued Below

But Jeffries' declaration for the No. 4 position leaves Pelosi critics without a leader they believe they can win with. The group has been trying to find someone willing to challenge Pelosi but has thus far been unsuccessful.

Jeffries' move is sure to shake up the caucus chair race. Current Vice Caucus Chair Linda Sánchez is also trying to move up the ladder to claim the position. And Rep. Barbara Lee, another Congressional Black Caucus member, has also been whipping for the post, sending care packages of candy to offices in her bid to woo lawmakers and candidates.

In his “Dear Colleagues” letter, Jeffries laid out his vision for the position, pointing specifically to President Donald Trump’s penchant for spinning facts to say that House Democrats must have a clear message in countering him. The position oversees communications for the caucus.

“There is an unconventional President in the Oval Office who dominates the news cycle with his outrageous claims, name-calling and falsehoods,” Jeffries wrote. “Undoubtedly, he will try to use the House Democratic Caucus as a foil to explain his shortcomings and inability to lead.”

He added: “Message discipline helped carry us into the majority. To stay in charge, we must act aggressively on a bold legislative agenda and consistently message to the American people what we are doing to improve their quality of life.”

SEVEN TAKEAWAYS from Tuesday’s election results:

-- POIZNER’s LOSS IS GAVIN’S GAIN: Many Republicans were hoping that tech executive and former Republican Steve Poizner would forge a path to elected office for moderate, business-friendly candidates in California — as an independent. And Poizner, in his second quest to be state insurance commissioner, not only had the experience, but the backing of 24 of 24 state newspaper endorsements to take it again. Thousands of votes still remain uncounted — but it appears Democratic state Sen. Ricardo Lara, who barely campaigned for the job, may now become the first openly elected gay statewide official. And that sigh of relief you hear is from the Gavin Newsom camp. Because had Poizner been successful, he would have been immediately on track to mount a decent, and possibly expensive challenge to Newsom for the top spot in 2022.

-- SCHOOLS SCUFFLE: There was no larger disconnect between money spent and actual power at stake than in the state superintendent of public instruction race, which pitted second-time candidate Marshall Tuck against state Assemblyman Tony Thurmond. But for the outside antagonists who plowed an astonishing $41 million into this race, this was really a test of whether charters and wealthy individuals who advocate expanding charter schools and changing teacher employment laws could hand a loss to the California Teachers Association and its allies in the Democratic Party. With Tuck sitting on a narrow lead, this could be the test. And if he’s successful, look to some moderates to tap Tuck for a run other offices in the future.

-- ASSEMBLY DISTRICT 15: BARACK VS. BERNIE, WICKS BEATS BECKLES: The Dem-on-Dem East Bay clash between Obama campaign alum Buffy Wicks and Richmond City Council member Jovanka Beckles saw dueling endorsements from former President Barack Obama and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and a late flood of cash from interest groups — proving that in single-party Sacramento, interests group care about the type of Democrat that wins. The more mainstream Wicks (whose strength in ground game politics was honed in the Obama ‘08 presidential campaign) prevailed handily in the end, denying Beckles a chance to become Sacramento’s lone democratic socialist.

-- ICE-DRIVEN TACK TO THE LEFT? If his lead holds and Andrew Villanueva pulls off a stunning upset and unseats L.A. County Sheriff Jim McDonnell, count it as more evidence of the state’s swing to the left. One of Villanueva’s central arguments in the race was that the sheriff's department need to take stronger measures to distance itself from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, as the LATimes reported. He was endorsed by progressive Kevin de León, the former state Senate president pro tem who challenged Sen. Dianne Feinstein (more on that race below). The race is still a nail-biter, but it could be a game changer on criminal justice.

-- FIRST FLIP: Democrat Mike Levin officially defeated Republican Diane Harkey in the 49th Distrist, the first red congressional seat California Dems have formally painted blue. Democrats worked to push Harkey into the general, and frustrated Republicans pointed to her lackluster performance -- like this rambling Q&A . Even outgoing Rep. Darrell Issa predicted Levin would claim his seat, which some point to as more evidence of the Trump collapse in the suburbs.

-- SECOND SWITCH: Soon after the AP called the 49th for Levin, GOP Rep. Steve Knight called Democrat Katie Hill to concede. Anchored in the high desert of northeastern Los Angeles County, the 25th District has seen Democrats gradually build their registration advantage in another suburban district. The charismatic young Hill got plenty of glowing national press, including a laudatory HBO doc of her campaign that airs its final installation tonight. Trailer here.

-- S.F.’s BENIOFF-BACKED PROP. C WON -- and S.F. Mayor London Breed lost bigtime, via SFExaminer’s Joe Fitzgerald Rodriguez: “Mayor London Breed wasn’t on November’s ballot, but holy hell did she lose this election. ... That measure, which will tax wealthy businesses to help solve our homeless crisis, was backed to the tune of roughly $10 million by — of all people! — Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff. Though granted he is a San Francisco native, who expected a literal representation of the Monopoly man to be more in touch with the will of San Franciscans than the mayor?” Story.

FRESH OFF THE MIDTERM: FIRING OF ATTORNEY GENERAL JEFF SESSIONS -- Two top Californians already in position to make a difference on what happens next:

-- Rep. Adam Schiff, soon to be head of House Intelligence: “It is abundantly clear that Sessions was forced out for following the advice of ethics lawyers at the Department of Justice and recusing himself from the Russia probe, and for failing to bring about an end to an investigation that has produced multiple indictments and convictions and may implicate the President or others around him."

This tells you that something is happening in the California electorate — that Democrats, Republicans and decline to state voters are uneasy with the status quo.’’
