A Democratic House sets up a grand bargain on trade

With help from Sabrina Rodriguez and Doug Palmer

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Trade is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Trade subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

THE DAY AFTER: A divided Congress could force the Trump administration to think about how it might get the votes to pass a new NAFTA deal. The election outcome spoke little to the impact of the president’s trade policies on voter decisions. And does a divided Washington mean that nothing gets done? Don’t count on it, especially if Democrats hope to tout a productive agenda ahead of 2020. Start here:

A DEMOCRATIC HOUSE SETS UP A GRAND BARGAIN ON TRADE: Let the dealmaking begin, especially if the Trump administration wants to get a new NAFTA deal through both houses of Congress. If the past is any guide, the White House can look at how a Republican administration struck a deal with congressional Democrats 11 years ago.

On May 10, 2007, then-President George W. Bush struck a deal with Democrats to set new standards on labor and environment protections in trade pacts. It could be a road map for the Trump administration to find common ground on trade issues.

“May 10 was a vital breakthrough,” said Rep. Sandy Levin (D-Mich.), who helped author the original agreement. “The challenge became to take the clear language in May 10, which was a breakthrough, and make it real.”

A grand bargain, but no grand strategy: Trade experts caution against thinking that House Democrats will use the opportunity to develop a cohesive policy for all trade negotiations.

“The Democrats are not going to make it easy for political reasons, but there’s a path there,” said Bill Reinsch, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. “I just don’t know if it has bigger meaning.”

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is looking to hit an almost mythical sweet spot for bipartisan trade cooperation with the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, but labor unions — a key motivator for securing Democratic votes — are already asking for more.

“We’re fighting to say this isn’t over and there are still gains to be had,” said Celeste Drake, trade policy specialist for the AFL-CIO. Read the full story here.

IT’S WEDNESDAY, NOV. 7! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host sadly missed the journalistic tradition of election night pizza because he was working from home on Tuesday. Got any post-election insights to share? Let me know: abehsudi@politico.com or @abehsudi.

Join POLITICO on Nov. 14 for special editorial conversations at The Salute to Military Spouses, a half-day summit to raise awareness of the challenges and contributions of these unsung heroes. As the exclusive media partner of the summit, POLITICO journalists will provide firsthand insight and intelligence on timely political and policy issues facing the military and military spouses. Topics include “Improving the financial stability of military families” and “Using tech to tackle the high unemployment rate of military spouses.” RSVP here.

A REFERENDUM ON TRUMP’S TRADE POLICIES? MAYBE NOT: Trump’s tariffs garnered much media attention over the past months, but Tuesday night’s results made no clear statement on how the electorate views the administration’s trade policies.

A CNN exit poll found that a third of voters say the policy has had no impact and 25 percent say the policy has helped their area’s economy. A remaining 30 percent of voters said Trump’s trade policies have hurt them.

But even in races in which Trump’s trade policies have had a big effect on the local economy, the issue didn’t seem to drive voting decisions at the polls.

In North Dakota, farmers stood by Trump: Republican Rep. Kevin Cramer ousted Sen. Heidi Heitkamp in North Dakota, flipping the major agriculture-producing state Trump won by 36 percentage points in 2016. Heitkamp sought to drive a wedge between North Dakotans and Trump on trade and tariffs. Farmers in the state — a major producer of soybeans and other ag-export goods — have been struck hard by retaliatory tariffs in response to Trump’s tariffs on U.S. trading partners.

But the president has remained popular there, and Cramer opted to urge patience with Trump on tariffs. More on Cramer’s win here.

Illinois district as a test for economic policy: Republican Mike Bost won reelection in Illinois’ 12th District. As Pro Trade’s Megan Cassella profiled, the race there demonstrated how an economic argument alone may not be enough to prevail among voters.

WHAT A DIVIDED WASHINGTON MEANS FOR THE NEXT TWO YEARS: Democrats will have to find policy victories where they can get them, while also avoiding two years of obstruction that could risk alienating swing voters ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

White House keeps it real: A senior administration official told POLITICO recently that no one has “a Pollyanna view of the world, that we’re all going to come together and do big things.” But the hope in the West Wing is that Democrats feel “it’s also in their best interests to look functional.”

Where bipartisan possibility lies: With a divided Congress, the Trump administration is expected to focus on forging an infrastructure deal with the two chambers and potentially work to rein in drug prices — two areas typically more aligned with liberals. That’s not to say we should expect a major breakthrough on either issue, but there’s hope in both parties for impactful reforms and projects that could get bipartisan support.

Where Trump will likely go it alone: If Trump can’t get Congress on board, he’s expected to pursue some policy goals via executive orders, especially on immigration and energy. Among the White House’s priorities are exporting more oil and natural gas. Megan, Nancy Cook and Gabby Orr have more here.

CHAMBER LOOKS FOR COMMON GROUND: Shortly after it was clear that Congress would be divided, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce appealed for a constructive path forward.

“Divided government does not — and cannot — mean gridlock. We urge each and every leader to find the middle ground on issues including immigration, infrastructure, and trade,” Chamber CEO and President Tom Donohue said in a statement.

“Now is the time for our elected leaders to train their focus on what can be achieved to keep up America’s economic momentum. There is much to do and no time to waste.”

NEAL POISED TO LEAD WAYS AND MEANS: Rep. Richard Neal is expected to take over the powerful House Ways and Means Committee in 2019, giving him strong oversight of Trump’s trade agenda. Neal, the current ranking member of the panel, would replace Rep. Kevin Brady (R-Texas).

Dealmaker reputation: Neal is known for his ability to work across the aisle. That means his chairmanship could bode well for building bipartisan support for congressional approval of USMCA. Ways and Means has influence over other major issues like tax law and Social Security, which could give him leverage over the president.

Where he stands on USMCA, other FTAs: Neal has called for stronger, more enforceable labor standards and environmental protections in USMCA. But while congressional Democrats have long been critical of U.S. trade policy, Neal has voted in favor of certain free trade agreements. Neal voted against NAFTA, but voted in favor of deals with South Korea and Peru.

Sabrina has more on where Neal falls on Trump’s trade agenda here.

A (SLIGHT) HOPE FOR EX-IM BANK: Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) is projected to take over as leader of the Financial Services Committee. In that role, she is expected to push to reauthorize the Export-Import Bank next September.

The embattled bank, seen by outgoing Financial Services Chairman Jeb Hensarling (R-Texas) as an example of crony capitalism, still faces a major hurdle in the Senate, where Republican Sen. Pat Toomey is blocking new appointments to its board. The board has too few members to reach a quorum required to approve loans for transactions of more than $10 million. Read more from Pro Financial Services’ Zach Warmbrodt here.

DE MINIMIS FOOTNOTE CREATES BIG FUSS: For something that is supposedly too trivial or minor to merit consideration, the U.S. “de minimis” threshold for taxes on package shipments is getting a lot of attention.

The provision waives taxes and duties on incoming packages worth $800 or less. U.S. negotiators failed in the NAFTA renegotiation talks to persuade Canada and Mexico to raise their thresholds to a similarly high level. But they did include a footnote allowing the Trump administration to reduce the U.S. level to match Canada or Mexico’s.

That prompted the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the National Retail Federation, the Internet Association and other groups to urge Lighthizer to drop the footnote. To read more, click here.

GROUPS PRESS FOR DIGITAL TRADE CHAPTER IN NEW DEALS: Another coalition of more than 30 business groups sent Lighthizer a letter urging him to include a digital trade chapter in prospective agreements with the European Union, Japan and United Kingdom. It was the latest sign of uncertainty about exactly what issues the pacts will cover.

“Strong digital trade outcomes in the EU, Japan, and U.K. negotiations will help counter these growing restrictions on U.S. trade and set examples for other countries developing their own digital trade rules,” the Internet Association and other groups said. “The administration would miss an opportunity with three of our most important trading partners if it omitted digital trade from the negotiations.”

Malmström, Lighthizer meeting next week: The push comes as Lighthizer is preparing to host European Union Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström a week from today, a senior EU diplomat told our colleagues in Brussels. Lighthizer notified Congress last month of his intention to negotiate a trade agreement with the EU, but the exact scope of the negotiations remains unclear. That’s partly because the United States is pushing to include agriculture in the deal, while the EU is resisting.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs had no impact on NAFTA negotiations, CNN reports.

— The head of Airbus in China warns that a U.S.-China trade conflict will hurt China’s aviation industry, The Financial Times reports.

— An economist who accurately predicted the U.S.-China trade fights says there will be a resolution reached in 2019, Bloomberg reports.

— The CEO of a major Canadian auto parts company said Trump’s tariffs are taking a toll, Fortune reports.

Wave breaks on GOP House control

With help from Arthur Allen (@arthurallen202) and Mohana Ravindranath (@ravindranize)

IN CONGRESS

Story Continued Below

WAVE BREAKS ON REPUBLICAN HOUSE CONTROL: Democrats have — by all indications — taken the House Tuesday night, while the GOP tightened their grip on the Senate. The result likely rules out another GOP-led attempt to repeal and replace Obamacare, and sets House Democrats up to police the Trump administration’s management of health care policy.

We might also see bipartisan national privacy legislation, which, depending on how it’s handled, might jostle regulation of the health sector. (We discussed the possibility here.)

The changeover, of course, means a new cast of characters chairing the important committees. In the House, we’re likely to see Rep. Frank Pallone chairing the Energy and Commerce Committee and Rep. Mark Takano (likely) leading the Veterans’ Affairs Committee. Both chairs will play a role in monitoring the Trump administration’s activities — in particular the VA’s implementation of the Cerner EHR.

eHealth tweet of the day: Paul Kedrosky @pkedrosky “Machine learning, but for making US healthcare plan choices during annual open enrollment: I hate the endless options, & the general feeling you're missing a crucial footnote that will cause a guy in camo scrubs to break in and remove your liver as partial payment for something.”

WEDNESDAY: Your correspondent hopes everyone had a nice, non-stressful voting experience — your correspondent waited about a half-hour to cast his ballot in D.C., which is altogether not so bad. What issues are you hoping a new Congress will address in 2019? Drop your correspondent a line at dtahir@politico.com. Discuss issues at @arthurallen202, @dariustahir, @ravindranize, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_eHealth.

As the exclusive media partner of the summit, POLITICO journalists will provide firsthand insight and intelligence on timely political and policy issues facing the military and military spouses. Topics include “Improving the financial stability of military families” and “Using tech to tackle the high unemployment rate of military spouses.” RSVP here.

AI — SMART IN ALL SETTINGS?: Deep learning tools that were trained to detect pneumonia on chest X-rays in one hospital system were much less effective at detecting the disease on scans from two other systems, according to a study published Tuesday in PLOS Medicine.

Researchers at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York City compared the ability of their algorithm combinations — called convolutional neural networks — to detect disease on images from Mount Sinai Hospital with images from NIH and Indiana University hospitals. In three out of five comparisons on a total of 158,000 X-rays, performance on the outside hospitals’ X-rays was significantly lower than on X-rays from Mount Sinai.

“Our findings should give pause to those considering rapid deployment of artificial intelligence platforms without rigorously assessing their performance in real-world clinical settings,” said senior author Eric Oermann in a news release. “Patient populations and imaging techniques differ significantly across institutions.”

The findings point to fundamental difficulties in using AI in health care, Parsa Mirhaji, director of clinical research informatics at Montefiore Medical Center in New York, told POLITICO.

AI learns from the particular relationships of data, and not the clinical phenomena they represent, he said. “That makes it susceptible to variations and heterogeneity in data” resulting from differences in how the data is represented and in the different health systems’ clinical processes.

INSIDE THE HUMPHREY BUILDING

HHS GEARS GRIND ON: Meanwhile, HHS continued to keep active Tuesday. Here are the latest updates:

— FDA: FDA released a new, open-source app Tuesday intended to help researchers collect real-world data.

The app, called "MyStudies," is intended to ease the gathering of reliable real-world data, including from EHRs and patients.

"Our hope is that the collection of more real world data directly from patients, using a secure app, will lead to more efficient product development and assist with safety monitoring," FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb said in a news release.

The app was tested in partnership with Kaiser Permanente, which deployed it to interact with pregnant women in a study dealing with sleep patterns and medication use. FDA is now releasing the app as open-source code for researchers to use.

The agency also released guidance on unique device identifier compliance for Class I and unclassified devices (i.e. the very least risky medical devices out there). Depending on when the device is labeled, manufacturers will have to submit identifiers in September 2020 or 2021.

— CDC RFI: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is in the middle of a request for information process on the creation of a national testbed to assess how health IT can deliver best evidence to providers while they’re using care. Final responses are due Dec. 20, and the webpage for the RFI is here.

— ASPE RFI: HHS’ Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation also has an RFI, and the commentary period is concluding soon. ASPE wants to know how plans and providers are addressing Medicare patients’ social risks to health — including whether social risk data is being used to target services — and is asking for commentary. That’s due Nov. 16, and the RFI page is here.

HEALTH IT BUSINESS WATCH

SAMSUNG SMARTPHONE-CONTROLLED INSULIN PUMP PROJECT: Insulet Corporation, an insulin pump manufacturer, has a new collaboration with Samsung Electronics America, the firms are announcing today. The idea is for Insulet’s insulin pump to be managed by a Samsung Galaxy smartphone — a new advance for the field.

Some glucose monitors beam their data to phones, and some hackers have rigged together monitors, pumps and computers to adjust insulin doses automatically. This is a more formal approach to adjusting insulin dosage by mobile device. “It’s groundbreaking,” Dave Rhew, Samsung Electronics America’s chief medical officer, told Morning eHealth, though the combination hasn’t been approved by the FDA.

Rhew said that the collaboration wasn’t delivered through FDA’s pre-certificaton pilot process (which Samsung is part of), but touted the security of the smartphone, its software and the hook-up with Insulet’s device. “We have to be able to ensure this solution has the highest level of security,” he said.

While the fruits of the collaboration haven’t fully materialized, Rhew anticipates extending smartphones to help consumers manage more of their health. “As you think about the possibility of your smartphone being able to do everything with your health care, managing your devices, communicating with your physician, capturing data … the possibilities are tremendous,” he said, citing wellness data and EHR data as examples.

“We’ve got a single device people can use to manage their lifestyle and manage their medical condition,” he said.

— Other biz/tech notes: Alphabet’s holding a two-day conference for employees from its various health-related initiatives … startup Collective Health is adding a board member with experience taking companies public. … An interesting reaction from a Kaiser Permanente doc on Atul Gawande’s EHR article

USDA RURAL TELEMEDICINE REPORT: Telehealth advocates often tout the benefits of the technology for rural patients, but those patients may not be as receptive to it as their urban counterparts, a new study from USDA suggests.

About 17 percent of rural residents surveyed did health research online, 7 percent did health maintenance activities like checking records or paying bills online and 1.3 percent participated in remote monitoring — compared to 20 percent, 11 percent, and 2.5 percent in urban areas, respectively.

The analysis was conducted using the Census Bureau’s 2015 Current Population Survey data, so trends may have changed since then.

WHAT WE'RE CLICKING

Do genes play less of a role in longevity than we thought?

Allscripts plans on making PDMP data available on its EHRs.

Ciitizen — a startup helping patients control their data — details some of the spurious reasons providers use to restrict access to patient data.

It's over

With help from Ted Hesson

IT’S OVER: The Democrats won the House, but Republicans gained two seats in the Senate in races called so far. Here’s a rundown of labor and employment winners and losers now that the dust has settled:

Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), co-chair of the multiemployer pension supercommittee, won reelection easily. He campaigned on retirement security, Social Security and Medicare, and there’s some talk that he may run for president in 2020 (he says he has “no real interest”).

In Michigan, Democrat Andy Levin followed his father Sander’s footsteps into the House. Levin fils is a former union organizer, AFL-CIO official, and attorney who sat on President Bill Clinton’s labor law reform commission.

Rep. Conor Lamb (D-Pa.), the marine vet who earlier this year flipped Pennsylvania's 17th District in a nail-biter special election, won reelection easily. Lamb’s platform was heavily focused on union rights, winning him support from the United Steelworkers and the AFL-CIO. He billed himself as the “most effective ally” for protecting union rights and supporting prevailing wages.

DEMOCRATIC HOUSE: Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), ranking member on the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, is expected to become chairman. Democrats will likely exercise greater oversight and subpoena power over DOL and the NLRB.

Democrats have said they will put the “L” word back into the committee’s name, restoring it to the Committee on Education and Labor (which is what it was called before Republicans won a House majority).

Read more on Democratic leaders’ potential labor plans now that they’ve sealed the majority from POLITICO’s Ian Kullgren here.

GOVERNORSHIP ROUNDUP:

Unions are jubilant over the defeat of two of their bitterest enemies: Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Bruce Rauner of Illinois. Walker spearheaded a 2011 law that restricted severely the ability of public employees to bargain collectively, and in 2015 he signed a right-to-work bill into law. Rauner initiated the litigation that led to the Supreme Court’s Janus decision earlier this year, and has tangled nonstop with public employee unions.

Walker lost by just a couple thousand votes to Democrat Tony Evers, the state schools superintendent. Fight for $15 and the Service Employees International Union are taking some credit for Evers’ narrow victory. They say they operated the “single-largest voter engagement program” in Milwaukee, knocking on 273,659 doors and talking with 37,173 voters in the runup to Tuesday’s midterms. In reaction to Walker’s loss, the AFL-CIO didn’t mince words: “Scott Walker was a national disgrace.”

Rauner suffered a steeper defeat from Democrat J.B. Pritzker, who scored 54 percent of the vote in Illinois. Pritzker, who is worth around $3.2 billion, will also be the richest elected politician in the country, taking the title from President Donald Trump according to Forbes.

Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf (D) won by double digits over Republican challenger Scott Wagner with major support from unions. Wolf vowed in October to veto any legislation “that attacks workers’ rights,” including one that would bar union non-members from making voluntary fair-share contributions to the union through payroll deductions, according to the Billy Penn.

In Connecticut, it is still too close to call whether organized labor successfully backed Democrat Ned Lamont, a proponent of a $15 hourly minimum wage and paid family and medical leave, against Republican Bob Stefanowski, who opposed raising the minimum wage. Lamont is currently leading with only a few thousand votes.

IMMIGRATION

TRUMP’S IMMIGRATION PUSH: President Donald Trump’s intense focus on immigration before the midterms appeared to yield mixed results. Exit polls published by CNN showed 23 percent of voters considered immigration the most important issue facing the country, second only to health care, which 42 percent dubbed the top concern.

Notably, several Republicans closely aligned with Trump’s immigration policies were defeated by Democrats. Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach lost a bid to become governor of his state, Rep. Lou Barletta (R-Pa.) fell short in an attempt to win the seat held by Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.), and Rep. Dave Brat (R-Va.) lost a reelection campaign to Democrat (and former CIA agent) Abigail Spanberger. Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa) — who drew fire in the days before the election for his associations with white nationalists — was reelected by a narrow margin. Trump won the district by 27 percent in 2016.

ON THE BALLOT:

In Florida, voters agreed to ban vaping, including the use of electronic cigarettes, in enclosed indoor workplaces.

Voters in both Arkansas and Missouri approved a raise to the state minimum wage. In Arkansas, the hourly minimum will increase to $11 per hour (up from $8.50) by 2021. Missouri will gradually increase the state’s minimum to $12 an hour by 2023 (up from $7.85). After that it will rise automatically with the consumer price index. Government employees, though, are exempt from the wage hike.

Voters gave the Arizona legislature the green light to make cuts to shore up two of the state’s pension plans for correctional officers and elected officials. Benefit increases will now be based on “a cost of living adjustment tied to inflation,” and corrections officers hired on or after July 1, 2018 will be transitioned to a defined contribution system. The move is expected to save taxpayers $275 million.

California voters agreed to exempt private ambulance employees from California labor laws requiring that hourly employees be given certain rest and meal breaks without being on call. Private ambulance drivers will be paid at their normal rate during breaks and will remain on call so that they are able to more promptly respond to emergencies.

Colorado residents voted to remove a provision in the state constitution that permits “involuntary servitude” for criminals.

Oregon voters rejected Measure 105, which would have repealed the state’s sanctuary law limiting state cooperation in enforcing federal immigration laws.

A measure in Massachusetts that would have limited how many patients could be assigned to nurses in hospitals and certain other health care facilities was quashed by voters Tuesday.

But, the Commonwealth’s voters overwhelmingly agreed to uphold a law barring discrimination based on gender identity in public places. The law had support from the business community, which feared a potential economic backlash if the protections were rolled back. More on that from the Boston Business Journal here.

SUPREME COURT

AGE DISCRIMINATION: The Supreme Court said Tuesday that the Age Discrimination in Employment Act applies to all state and local government employers, no matter how small. The Age Discrimination and Employment Act defines an employer as any business that employs 20 or more people but says it “also means” any “State or political subdivision of a State.” The case turned on the meaning of the phrase “also means;” the high court concluded it meant the anti-discrimination law applied to state and local government entities that employed fewer than 20 people--in this instance, a fire department in Arizona. The high court’s decision was unanimous, a relative rarity in employment-related cases.

The ruling gives ADEA broader reach than Title VII, which applies only to government entities with 15 or more employees. That means “scores of litigants alleging age discrimination claims will now have access to federal court," according to Randi May, employment law partner at Hoguet Newman Regal & Kenney, LLP. Read the opinion here.

CHINESE WORKERS TO WISCONSIN: At a campaign event last month for Gov. Scott Walker, President Donald Trump touted as the “most incredible plan” Taiwan-based Foxconn’s move to build its first U.S. plant in Wisconsin. But despite Foxconn’s promise to hire 13,000 employees, the Wall Street Journal reports that the tight labor market now has the company considering whether to bring in Chinese workers.

Foxconn told the Journal that its “Wisconsin first commitment remains unchanged” and that it still plans to hire 13,000 workers for “high-value production and engineering assignments and in the research and development field.” More from the Wall Street Journal here.

LAWSUIT OVER FINGERPRINT DELAYS: A class-action lawsuit filed Tuesday says new fingerprint checks for potential sponsors of detained unaccompanied migrant children have delayed the minors’ release. “These delays have caused the length of time that children spend in government custody to spike dramatically,” the complaint says, “and the total number of children in government custody to balloon to its highest in history.” The Wall Street Journal reported in October that the average length of stay for an unaccompanied minor in federal custody stood at 59 days — a 44 percent increase from the previous year. Read the complaint here.

STOCK FOR GIG WORKERS: As more apps such as Airbnb, Uber and Lyft weigh going public (Uber was recently valued at $120 billion), the Securities and Exchange Commission may make it easier for gig workers classified as independent contractors to own stock in these companies, David Gelles reports for The New York Times.

Federal securities law, Gelles reports, bars private companies from issuing shares to contractors. “In considering a change, the S.E.C. is tacitly acknowledging that for all the value gig economy companies are creating, they are also, in some ways, contributing to the stark income inequality that is roiling society,” he writes. But if the rules are changed and gig workers receive stock without a way to sell it, Gelles warns that workers “could be liable for taxes on those gains, without having any easy way” to pay them. More from the Times here.

Coffee Break

— “Most rich democracies don’t hold their elections during the workweek,” from The Washington Post

— “Google Workers Reject Silicon Valley Individualism in Walkout,” from The New York Times

— Opinion: “The missing piece of NAFTA 2.0,” from The Hill

House Democrats expected to ramp up oversight of DeVos

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

HOUSE DEMOCRATS EXPECTED TO RAMP UP OVERSIGHT OF DEVOS: Democrats seized control of the House on Tuesday night, likely placing Rep. Bobby Scott in charge of the House education committee. And that means the hot seat is about to get even hotter for Education Secretary Betsy DeVos. More from Kimberly Hefling.

Story Continued Below

— Democrats on the campaign trail this cycle used DeVos as a symbol of what's wrong with President Donald Trump’s policies, pushing ads that portrayed her as an out-of-touch billionaire and enemy of public education intent on unraveling civil rights and higher education consumer protections. With Democrats’ takeover of the House, they gain new authority to propel DeVos — and her top aides — to testify or turn over documents.

— The stage is set for at least two showdowns in the coming months — the Trump administration will soon propose a new regulation on the handling of campus sexual assault cases under Title IX, the federal law that prohibits sex-based discrimination in federally funded education programs. And a White House school safety commission led by DeVos is set to release a report on its findings since the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. The Trump administration’s push to unravel Obama-era regulations aimed at the for-profit college industry and its handling of state plans under the Every Student Succeeds Act are also areas that Democrats will likely target for oversight.

— Scott (D-Va.) is expected to lead the way. A veteran lawmaker and stalwart on civil rights who was the first African-American elected to Congress from Virginia since Reconstruction, he has been ranking member since 2015. During that time, he helped negotiate the bipartisan ESSA, the federal education law that replaced No Child Left Behind. Two of Scott’s staffers — Jacque Mosely and Véronique Pluviose — will likely play a more prominent role now that Democrats hold the majority. Read up on Scott here.

— Look to Scott to push a legislative agenda focused on passage of his Rebuild America’s Schools Act, H.R. 2475 (115), which would invest billions of dollars in new funding into improving school infrastructure. Another big priority is an update to the Higher Education Act — a heavy lift under any political environment, but an item high on the wish list for many in higher education circles. Some education wonks are hopeful about a split Congress making progress on legislation, particularly when it comes to HEA and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, the federal law governing the privacy of student education records. Read more on Democrats’ plans.

— Meanwhile, Rep. Virginia Foxx (R-N.C.), the Republican chairwoman of the House education committee, defeated her opponent D.D. Adams on Tuesday night. Adams, a Democrat, serves on the Winston-Salem City Council. Scott ran unopposed.

MIDTERMS WATCH

‘BLUE WAVE’ ELUDES GOVERNORS RACES: Democrats cut into some Republican-held governorships on Tuesday night, but failed to take others. As a result, there’s something for everyone when it comes to school funding, school choice and other issues. Gubernatorial and state legislative races could have the biggest effect on education policy in the states. Here are the results from some of the races our team has been watching closely:

— WISCONSIN: Tony Evers, the Democrat in charge of the state’s public school system, defeated Republican Gov. Scott Walker, who was seeking a third term as governor. The close race pitted Walker in the fight of his political life, forcing him to grapple with his record on education — one that included funding cuts during the early years of his administration and a 2010 law that essentially gutted the state teachers union.

— GEORGIA: The race between Democrat Stacey Abrams and Republican Brian Kemp, in another nail-biter of a gubernatorial race plagued with voting drama, had not been called by early today. While both pledged to invest more in public education, Abrams proposed eliminating the state’s tax credit scholarship program and Kemp said he’d maintain it.

— FLORIDA: Democrat Andrew Gillum conceded to Republican Ron DeSantis in a tight race that attracted national attention. Gillum pledged to raise the corporate income tax rate from 5.5 percent to 7.75 percent to raise $1 billion for public schools, boost teachers’ starting salaries to $50,000 and shut down school choice in the Sunshine State. DeSantis backed more school choice options and merit-based pay for teachers, rather than an across-the-board pay raise.

— NEW MEXICO: Rep. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, won the open seat against GOP Rep. Steve Pearce. Grisham campaigned on a plan to fund universal preschool, while Pearce campaigned in favor of improving traditional K-12 schools. A new governor will likely mean changes for the state’s plan for holding schools accountable under ESSA — both candidates favored scrapping the Common Core-aligned PARCC test and overhauling the state’s teacher evaluation system.

— OKLAHOMA: Republican Kevin Stitt beat Democrat Drew Edmondson — a disappointing result for the grassroots #RedforEd movement that grew out of widespread teacher unrest and called for big investments in public education funding. Edmonson supported the tax hikes designed to fund teacher raises in the state, which came in response to massive teacher walkouts earlier this year. But Stitt told the Tulsa World in June that he didn’t support the measure or new taxes.

— OHIO: Richard Cordray, a Democrat and President Barack Obama’s former head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, lost to Mike DeWine, the state’s Republican attorney general. Throughout the race, Democrats sought to tie DeWine to the collapse of a massive online charter school.

— KANSAS: Democrat Laura Kelly defeated Republican Kris Kobach, the Trump-supported candidate and secretary of state who backed a state law that would require 75 percent of school funding to be spent on classroom instruction. Kobach tweeted in June: “Classrooms are my priority. ‘Crystal Palaces’ to house bureaucrats, designer atriums and exclusive staff-only fitness centers and aerobics studios are not my priority.” Kelly, a state senator, pledged to direct more money to schools after the Kansas Supreme Court ruled that the state had to increase education funding.

— ARIZONA: Republican Gov. Doug Ducey beat David Garcia, a professor with a background in education policy. The state was one of several this year where teachers went on strike and school funding and private school choice were prominent issues in the race. Ducey, who led Garcia in the polls, often pointed to the measure he signed earlier this year to address the teacher unrest, providing teachers with a 20 percent raise by 2020.

— COLORADO: Rep. Jared Polis, a Democrat, defeated Republican state Treasurer Walker Stapleton. Polis, a member of the House education committee who founded two charter schools, has called for more school funding and campaigned on a pledge to make preschool and full-day kindergarten free. He’ll be the first openly gay governor in the U.S.

— ILLINOIS: Teachers unions were eager to oust Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner, who lost on Tuesday night to his Democratic opponent, billionaire J.B. Pritzker. In polls, Rauner had trailed Pritzker, who has funded early childhood education efforts nationwide. Rauner was at war with teachers unions in the state — in 2015, he launched the lawsuit that would eventually become the Janus case.

— MICHIGAN: Teachers unions were also campaigning in the final days for Gretchen Whitmer, who defeated Republican Attorney General Bill Schuette after leading him in the polls.

HOW EDUCATION BALLOT INITIATIVES FARED: School funding, school choice, religious displays in schools and education governance questions were among the issues decided by voters on Tuesday. Here are some of the results:

— ARIZONA: Voters rejected an expansion of the state’s education savings account program, which allows families to draw public funds to pay for private school tuition and other education-related expenses. The question was added to the ballot after public school advocates successfully collected enough signatures in protest of the law. A Suffolk University/Arizona Republic poll last month suggested that voters were confused about what the ballot initiative would do.

— ALABAMA: Voters overwhelmingly backed a referendum allowing the Ten Commandments to be displayed in schools and other public buildings — as long as it's part of a display with historical or educational items.

— COLORADO: Voters rejected an initiative that would raise corporate taxes and state income taxes for people earning $150,000 annually. It's estimated that $1.6 billion would have been generated for K-12 education.

— OKLAHOMA: Voters narrowly rejected a ballot initiative that would’ve allowed school leaders to tap into funding typically reserved for school construction and use it in other ways, like for increasing teacher salaries. Stitt supported the measure, but Edmondson said it could increase disparities among school districts and could be used by the state legislature as a way to avoid spending on public education.

— SOUTH CAROLINA: Voters shot down a ballot initiative that would allow the governor to appoint the state superintendent of education starting in 2023 — keeping the superintendent position an elected office.

VOTERS PICK STATE EDUCATION CHIEFS: Voters in seven states elected a new state school chief. Here are the results:

— CALIFORNIA: The race between Marshall Tuck and fellow Democrat Tony Thurmond had not been called by early today. The race was closely watched, in part, because it generated more than $40 million in contributions. Tuck, the former president of a charter school organization who also was the CEO of an initiative that runs 18 district schools in Los Angeles, lost his bid for the nonpartisan seat in 2014. He was the heavy favorite among members of the education reform community, which favors charter schools. Thurmond, a Democratic state legislator and former social worker, had the backing of teachers unions.

— ARIZONA: The race between Democrat Kathy Hoffman, a speech pathologist and political newcomer with ties to the #RedforEd teacher strike movement, and Frank Riggs, a Republican charter school executive and former California congressman, had not been called by early today. The two tangled over issues of experience, oversight of charter schools, school funding and school safety.

— OKLAHOMA: State Superintendent of Public Instruction Joy Hofmeister, a Republican, held her post against Democrat John Cox, the superintendent of rural Peggs Public Schools. The race, in a year in which the state saw an uprising among teachers, was a rematch between the two, who also faced off in 2014. Larry Huff, a retired educator, also ran for the seat as an independent.

— GEORGIA: Richard Woods, the state’s Republican state superintendent, held off a challenge from Otha Thornton, a retired Army officer running as a Democrat. Thornton was the first black male president of the National PTA.

— IDAHO: The race between Democrat Cindy Wilson, a high school government teacher, and incumbent Republican Sherri Ybarra, also a former teacher and school administrator, had not been called by early today. Wilson campaigned on improving early childhood education and criticized a $20 million school safety proposal by Ybarra that focused heavily on hiring school security personnel.

— SOUTH CAROLINA: After shooting down a referendum that would have given the governor power to appoint the state's superintendent starting in 2023, voters reelected Superintendent of Education Molly Spearman, a Republican. Spearman, a former teacher and school administrator who supported having the governor make the appointment, was unopposed. Her opponent, Democrat Israel Romero, a former teacher and professor, dropped out of the race before the election.

— WYOMING: Jillian Balow, a Republican who is the current superintendent of public instruction, ran unopposed. Balow is a former teacher who worked in various state administration positions before being elected in 2014.

TEACHERS RUNNING FOR OFFICE: The National Education Association has identified 1,800 educators running for state legislative seats. Its count includes current and retired teachers and those who work in higher education. In a year that was awash with teacher unrest, several of the teacher candidates in Oklahoma, Arizona, West Virginia and elsewhere said they were motivated by school funding issues to run. NEA, which is tracking the outcomes of the teacher races, didn’t have a count of how many won on Tuesday night.

— Outside of state legislative races: One of the most high-profile teacher candidates for federal office was Jahana Hayes, a Democratic candidate for the House in Connecticut who defeated Republican Manny Santos. Hayes was the 2016 National Teacher of the Year.

— Two education activists who ran for Congress: West Virginia state legislator Richard Ojeda, who became a hero among teachers striking in the state earlier this year, ran as a Democrat for West Virginia’s 3rd District. He lost to Republican Carol Miller. And in Alaska, independent Alyse Galvin unsuccessfully sought to unseat Republican Rep. Don Young. In early 2017, Galvin launched a campaign to urge both of Alaska’s senators to reject DeVos’ confirmation.

Affirmative Action

MARK YOUR CALENDARS: In non-midterm-related news, arguments have been scheduled for Feb. 13 in the closely watched court case over Harvard University’s use of race in admissions. The university is defending itself against a lawsuit that claims its admissions process is unfair to Asian-American applicants. Earlier this month, three weeks of testimony in the case wrapped up. But Judge Allison Burroughs offered both sides a chance to make a last round of arguments.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— Children tend to have higher levels of school engagement when involved in one or more activities, like sports, lessons or clubs, according to a new report from the Census Bureau.

— A new report by the Institute of Education Sciences finds that the average tuition and required fees at four-year public institutions increased more than 2 percent for both in-state and out-of-state students, when adjusted for inflation, between 2015-16 and 2017-18. A separate report released by IES found that public four-year institutions received about 21 percent of their revenues from tuition and fees in fiscal 2017.

SYLLABUS

— Gov.-elect Bill Lee says Tennessee schools rank in the nation’s bottom. They’re not. Chalkbeat.

— Casino “lockbox” for Maryland school funding wins approval: The Baltimore Sun.

— In referendum, Newark voters decide to stick with an elected school board: Chalkbeat.

— The Parkland survivors pen a post-Election Day op-ed: “The school shooting changed our lives, and young people flooded the polls to change America.” Miami Herald.

— Every proposed local education tax passed in Florida: POLITICO Florida.

— Why did suspensions go up in New York City last year? Schools Chancellor Richard Carranza draws a link to fatal school stabbing: Chalkbeat.

— Paperwork backlog delays benefits to veterans attending Wichita State: Wichita Eagle.

— Noble charter network CEO Michael Milkie resigns: Chalkbeat.

— Cornell will keep Title IX protection for transgender individuals, university administrators say: The Cornell Daily Sun.

— Prison education programs are thriving and enjoy bipartisan backing, but colleges say they could do more with federal and state funding: Inside Higher Ed.

How midterms will shake up cybersecurity agenda

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Cristiano Lima

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

THE NEW SLATE — The House flipped to Democrats on Election Day, a development that promises to reorient the congressional cybersecurity agenda even though Republicans held on to the Senate. What will emboldened House Democrats try to get done? The Russia investigation in the House Intelligence Committee should roar back to life. The party has vowed to devote considerably more funding for election security. Long-stalled data breach legislation will get a fresh push and a more aggressive bent. And Democrats promise to take a more hawkish posture on supply chain threats. Pros can read our full breakdown here.

KEY RACE RESULTS — Claire McCaskill, top Democrat on the Senate Homeland Security Committee, lost reelection. On that panel, she has placed a big emphasis on supply chain security. She sponsored legislation (S. 3085) to create a council that would evaluate the government's risks when purchasing IT and communications technology from companies like Moscow-based Kaspersky Lab. The panel approved that bill in September.

Last month, McCaskill joined with Chairman Ron Johnson in seeking a briefing on a controversial Bloomberg story that reported China had implanted chips into hardware used by major U.S. companies. McCaskill earlier this year found herself the target of hackers who tried to infiltrate her office network, without success. The attacks, traced to Russia, were a response to her vocal stance against the Kremlin's aggression in cyberspace, McCaskill said.

Meanwhile, Bill Nelson, the top Democrat on both the Senate Commerce Committee and Armed Services Cybersecurity Subcommittee, appeared to lose his reelection bid. Nelson took heat this year for remarks about Russian hackers getting into Florida’s voter registration system.

In the House, Will Hurd appears to have won, although not without late drama. He’s the chairman of the Oversight Subcommittee on Information Technology and one of Congress’ leading cybersecurity voices. Republican Rep. Tom Reed defeated Democratic challenger Tracy Mitrano, a cyber specialist who argued Congress needs more lawmakers who are digitally savvy.

DEM LEADERS’ OVERSIGHT PRIORITIES — The incoming class of expected Democratic committee chairmen often team up on cybersecurity oversight, such as when they released a joint statement just last month about a briefing from Trump administration officials they said contradicted the president’s claims about Chinese election interference. But each have offered clues about their specific agenda.

On the Homeland Security Committee, Rep. Bennie Thompson is a persistent, across-the-board critic of the Trump administration’s cybersecurity policies and practices, and he has focused heavily on election security as co-chair of a Democratic task force with his House Administration counterpart Robert Brady. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the top Democrat on Judiciary, has asked for committee hearings into DHS’ conclusion that Russia was able to access voter registration systems in 2016, and top Energy and Commerce Democrat Frank Pallone has prodded the panel to hold hearings on 2016 election interference, too.

On the Foreign Affairs Committee, top Democrat Eliot Engel has asked for a panel investigation into the one-on-one meeting between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Top House Oversight Democrat Elijah Cummings sought a committee subpoena about former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson’s decision to eliminate the department’s cybersecurity office. House Science ranking Democrat Eddie Bernice Johnson has asked the panel leadership to investigate cybersecurity missteps regarding mobile phone practices in the Trump White House.

OUTGOING GOP LEADERS — The ranks of GOP committee leaders in the House will thin considerably on panels with a cybersecurity focus. Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul hit a GOP-imposed term limit. Judiciary’s Bob Goodlatte, Oversight’s Trey Gowdy, Science’s Lamar Smith, Foreign Affairs’ Ed Royce, Administration’s Gregg Harper and Appropriations’ Rodney Frelinghuysen are all retiring.

A number of key subcommittee leaders are exiting, too. Science’s Research and Technology Subcommittee Chairwoman Barbara Comstock and House Appropriations Homeland Security Subcommittee Chairman Kevin Yoder both lost. Rep. Marsha Blackburn, who chairs The Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Communications and Technology, won her bid for a Senate seat.

NO BIG INTERRUPTIONS … — DHS and its information sharing teammates didn’t pick up any evidence that foreign hackers or anyone else compromised election infrastructure Tuesday, department officials told reporters repeatedly throughout the day in a series of background briefings. Most of the calls took just several minutes, as there wasn’t much to report. There were plenty of technical problems on Tuesday, but "we continue to not see any sort of malicious actor indications behind any of these events," a DHS official said in the afternoon. The department and watchdog group Common Cause did, however, see some misinformation campaigns on social media, but posts were swiftly removed.

Facebook’s cybersecurity chief Nathaniel Gleicher confirmed just before midnight Tuesday that the action it took against 115 accounts on Facebook and Instagram a night prior was due to “concerns that they were linked to the Russia-based Internet Research Agency (IRA) and engaged in coordinated inauthentic behavior.” Gleicher added that the company blocked more Instagram accounts Tuesday after a website claiming to be tied to the IRA published a list of pages they created, though he did not specify how many. “We had already blocked most of these accounts yesterday, and have now blocked the rest,” he said, per our friends at Morning Tech.

... BUT THE SHOW ISN’T OVER — DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen said Tuesday she is worried about foreign agitators portraying the results of the election as invalid, because it could foster mistrust in U.S. democracy. “They win if they sow any doubt,” she said at a press conference. Other DHS officials and cybersecurity experts share that fear. Alex Stamos, Facebook’s former security chief, raised the subject during a discussion on Twitter about voter fraud and suppression. “This will happen from domestic groups no matter the outcome, with varying levels of evidence,” said Stamos, now a fellow at Stanford University. “The wildcard is whether any organized actors are planning on taking credit for any wins or will claim to have hacked election infrastructure.”

ABOUT THOSE IVANKA VOTING MACHINES — A spokesman for Ivanka Trump’s ethics attorney offered further information Tuesday about why she received approval for a trademark on voting machines. “These trademark applications were filed in the first half of 2016, well before President Trump won the election or Ms. Trump joined the Administration,” said Peter Mirijanian on behalf of the attorney, Abbe Lowell. “These trademarks were sought to broadly protect Ms. Trump’s name, and to prevent others from stealing her name and using it to sell their products. This is a common trademark practice, which is why the trademark applications were granted.”

BE BETTER BUILDERS — The technical standards agency NIST has released a guide showing how manufacturers can improve their cybersecurity practices, and the agency is seeking public comments on it. “The examples provided in this [document] demonstrate how detecting anomalous conditions can improve the reliability of manufacturing and other [industrial control systems], in addition to providing the demonstrated cybersecurity benefits,” the document’s introduction says. The guide offers advice for deploying behavioral anomaly detection, or BAD, capabilities, in two example scenarios: “a collaborative robotics-based manufacturing system and a process control 247 system (PCS) that resembles what is being used by chemical manufacturing industries.” The document is part of a NIST project to help manufacturers assess their vulnerabilities and improve their defenses. The public comment period runs through Dec. 6.

TEHRAN AND ON AND ON — Newly reimposed U.S. sanctions could spur Iran’s hackers to get more aggressive around the globe, according to a report from the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. “No nation has felt the full power of U.S. economic coercion quite like Iran, and therefore no regime is better positioned to understand how attacks on economic assets can undermine a nation’s military capabilities,” said Samantha Ravich, senior adviser and principal investigator of FDD’s Cyber-Enabled Economic Warfare project.

TWEET OF THE DAY — To me, that’s preposterous. Crabs on Krebs, things of that nature.

PEOPLE ON THE MOVE

— President Donald Trump this week announced the appointment of Brian Harrell to the position of assistant secretary for infrastructure protection at DHS. Harrell previously served as managing director of enterprise security at Duke Energy. He also previously served as director for critical infrastructure protection programs at the North American Electric Reliability Corp. and director of the Electricity Information Sharing and Analysis Center.

QUICK BYTES

— “'Almost all' Pakistani banks hacked in security breach.” Dawn

— HSBC said a small percentage of its U.S. bank customers’ accounts was hacked. BBC

— Georgia voters filed suit against Secretary of State Brian Kemp to prevent him from administering the election while running for governor, partially citing his controversial last-minute investigation of the state Democratic party over hacking claims. NBC News

— Russians might have been more active than ever in the midterms. The New York Times

— "The government’s cybersecurity standards agency will launch a process this year to make it easier to verify government employees’ identities when they access government data on mobile devices." Nextgov

— Symantec shares rose upon news that a private equity firm expressed interest in buying it. CNBC

That’s all for today. Pretty solid movie, too.

What's next for the farm bill

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

WHEW! LONG NIGHT: With Democrats set to take charge of the House next year, the pressure’s on House Ag Chairman Mike Conaway to get a farm bill done in the lame-duck session to salvage conservative elements of his bill. Also on the Democrats’ ag agenda: USDA oversight.

Story Continued Below

— Senate Republicans padded their majority thanks in large part to farm-state races. Democrats also pulled off some upsets in Midwestern gubernatorial and House contests.

— A new reality for the Trump trade agenda: House Democrats will have a hand in controlling the fate of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement and any trade deals that follow.

— Missed any of the results Tuesday night? MA’s got you covered, from ag-flavored House, Senate and governor’s races to ballot initiatives.

WHAT’S NEXT FOR THE FARM BILL: House Republicans have a SNAP decision to make. Conaway and the GOP conference have to consider whether to give ground on some of the biggest farm bill disputes — like conservation, commodity policy, and, of course, work requirements for Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program recipients — to get a bill passed this year. Striking a deal while they still have the majority would help House Republicans preserve some of their priorities before they lose leverage, our Catherine Boudreau writes today.

If there’s no lame-duck deal: House Democrats could start from scratch when the new Congress begins next year. That may not be something industry wants to see. The Democratic members could seek to pull the farm bill to the left with amendments to rein in subsidies for wealthy farmers or to adjust federal crop insurance.

— Ranking member Collin Peterson, who won a close race Tuesday and is expected to retake the House Agriculture gavel, has said he doesn’t want to start over and write his own farm bill. (The Minnesota Democrat has embraced the Senate-passed bill, S. 3042 (115), which drew bipartisan support.)

“I think the farm bill gets done pretty fast,” said Callie Eideberg, senior policy manager at the Environmental Defense Fund. Chuck Conner, president of the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives, said he thinks Conaway “wanted this thing done in the lame-duck no matter what” the election outcome was.

On the other hand: Sen. Chuck Grassley predicted Democrats will wait to restart the farm bill process in 2019 so they can write legislation without the SNAP provisions in the current House measure, H.R. 2 (115). “I would guess, unless the House very quickly backs down on food stamps, that we’re going to have a one-year extension and debate a new farm bill next year,” the Iowa Republican told reporters on a conference call.

THE HOUSE AG AGENDA: Beyond the farm bill, Democrats will be in position to exert tougher oversight on USDA and push for action on immigration reform.

— Secretary Sonny Perdue’s plans to relocate two USDA research agencies outside of Washington next year could face more scrutiny. Democrats will also keep closer tabs on the trade pain across U.S. farm regions, as well as USDA’s mitigation efforts.

— Moderating factor: Peterson is arguably the chamber’s most conservative Democrat, so the committee’s leftward shift probably won’t be as dramatic as on other House panels.

FARM-STATE RACE RESULTS: Let’s run through some of the marquee elections across the Midwest and other agricultural regions that were key to Republicans boosting their Senate majority and Democrats seizing the House.

WHO’S IN: A bunch of House and Senate Agriculture Committee members were reelected.

— Senate Ag Democrats Amy Klobuchar (Minn.), Sherrod Brown (Ohio), Bob Casey (Pa.), Kirsten Gillibrand (N.Y.), Tina Smith (Minn.) and ranking member Debbie Stabenow (Mich.) each won six more years. So did Nebraska Republican Deb Fischer.

— Most House Ag lawmakers also earned new terms. But some of the Republican members might lose their committee seats when the panel is reapportioned to reflect the new majority.

— Rep. Michelle Lujan Grisham, who’s been a vocal defender of SNAP on House Ag, was elected governor of New Mexico. She’ll be the first Latina Democrat to serve in that role. Democrat Tim Walz was elected Minnesota governor.

— Republican Pete Stauber won the open Minnesota seat now held by retiring Democratic Rep. Rick Nolan, who had held onto his seat in 2016 even as his district voted for President Donald Trump.

WHO’S OUT: Joe Donnelly and Heidi Heitkamp. The Senate Ag Committee Democrats, two of the party’s most vulnerable members, were both unseated in red states that voted for Trump in 2016. Donnelly was defeated by Republican Mike Braun in Indiana, while Heitkamp lost handily to Rep. Kevin Cramer.

— House Rules Chairman Pete Sessions lost to Democrat Colin Allred. The Texas Republican was one of the highest-ranking lawmakers to go down.

— Just one House Ag Republican had lost to a Democratic challenger by the time MA reached its extended deadline early this morning: Rep. John Faso in New York. Reps. Rodney Davis (Ill.) and Steve King (Iowa) held on in close races.

TBD: In the Mississippi Senate special election, Republican Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith, another Agriculture Committee member, will face former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy in a runoff on Nov. 27.

— In California’s Central Valley, Republican Rep. Jeff Denham was in a toss-up race that hadn’t been called by MA’s deadline.

MIXED RESULTS ACROSS MIDWEST: Anyone wondering if Trump’s trade war — and the challenges it’s raised for farmers and ranchers — would dampen GOP support in midterm races in agricultural areas… didn’t get a clear answer on Tuesday. Election results from the Midwest were all over the place.

Republicans swept the Senate races in Indiana, Missouri, North Dakota and Tennessee. But Democrats picked off House seats or governorships in states like Illinois, Iowa and Kansas. ICYMI, here are a few more eyebrow-raising results from the heartland:

— Democrats’ big day in Kansas: Laura Kelly beat Republican Kris Kobach for the governorship, and Sharice Davids defeated GOP Rep. Kevin Yoder.

— In Iowa: Republican Gov. Kim Reynolds was elected to a full term, while Democratic challengers defeated two of the state’s three House Republican incumbents.

— Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker lost his reelection bid to Democrat Tony Evers. Democrats also flipped the governor’s mansions in Illinois and Michigan.

BLUE HOUSE MAKES LABOR KEY TO USMCA APPROVAL: With Democrats in charge of the House, the path to ratification for the new North American trade pact just got a little bit steeper. Trump’s signature trade achievement could still be approved in 2019, but Democrats are now in position to demand changes to labor and environmental provisions in the deal, Pro Trade’s Adam Behsudi reports today.

“The Democrats are not going to make it easy for political reasons, but there’s a path there,” said Bill Reinsch, senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He predicted Democrats will say “not good enough” on the agreement’s labor language and tell Trump’s trade officials to “go back to Mexico and do better.”

Labor groups could be instrumental in brokering a political understanding on trade between Trump and congressional Democrats to advance the new North American trade pact. Labor unions have already called for changes to the deal. Labor and environmental improvements could be less of a factor in potential trade deals with economically advanced economies like Japan and the EU.

Change of power at Ways and Means: Massachusetts Rep. Richard Neal is in line to take charge of the House panel that oversees trade policy. Pro Trade’s Sabrina Rodriguez dives into Neal’s record here.

ROW CROPS

— What can get done in a divided Congress: POLITICO’s Megan Casella, Nancy Cook and Gabby Orr take a look at the balance Democrats will need to strike between liberal activists shouting for impeachment and party leaders pushing for cooperation on issues like infrastructure, drug pricing and immigration. Pros, fast-forward to 2019 right here.

— Bipartisanship, sorta: Grassley said he might work better with a Democratic chairman than Conaway on one of his farm bill priorities: limiting subsidy payments to farmland owners who don’t live or work on the farm. (He clarified that he wasn’t rooting for a Democratic takeover.) Your host has more.

— Soda tax ballot initiatives: Oregon voters rejected ballot Measure 103, which would have banned new taxes on soda throughout the state, the Oregonian reports. Washington voters, on the other hand, appeared to have approved a similar measure, Initiative 1634, after the soda industry poured $20 million into the effort. More from the Olympian here.

— Arkansas Plant Board votes to OK in-crop dicamba use: The board tentatively approved a “petition for rulemaking” from farmers that seeks a June 15 cutoff date for spraying the herbicide next year; spraying after that date would be acceptable only through a special permit. One farmer told the board that dicamba is needed to fight pigweed, which has grown resistant to other herbicides. Here’s the Arkansas Democrat Gazette’s story.

— Farm sentiment jumps post-NAFTA deal: A monthly index from Purdue University and the CME Group found that producer sentiment about the farm economy was up about 19 percent from September. Optimism over the new North American trade pact, announced Sept. 30, juiced farm sentiment, according to producers surveyed.

— FDA approves first drug to reduce animal gas: The agency on Tuesday signed off on Experior, from animal health company Elanco, a drug that can reduce ammonia gas emissions from beef cattle waste. Here’s the announcement.

— Smithfield, EDF team up on butterfly habitats: The Environmental Defense Fund and pork producer Smithfield Foods are restoring monarch butterfly habitats around the edges of a Smithfield farm in northern Missouri. The butterfly population has declined as much as 95 percent since the 1980s, Fast Company reports. One reason: Pesticide and herbicide use on farms has killed off native milkweed plants, where the monarchs lay their eggs.

— USDA extends use of paper pots in organics: The department will allow organic farmers to continue using paper pots until further notice, Organic Insider writes. Earlier this year, USDA had set a December deadline for ending paper pot use.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! See you again tomorrow. In the meantime, drop us a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.
